author: {'steamid': '76561198101659776', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 221, 'last_played': 1709151331}
review: Tight rules with no faff. Very addictive gameplay with extremely interesting historical narrative. I found myself wanting to read and study more about this period after playing! Some reviewers have talked about a lack of replayability but I haven't found this to be the case at all. After finishing my first game, I eagerly jumped right back into my second and will start a third. I'm really enjoying trying to complete all the trials and get all the cool buildings built. I love the aspect of how your city develops over the centuries and how you begin to expand along the Nile Valley. I also love the aspect of building the grand structures like tombs and palaces, especially since these are real places.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998116681', 'num_games_owned': 3146, 'num_reviews': 600, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1709566516}
review:
It's a short 4x-ish game. Imagine Civilization, Sid Meier's, I, now boil and boil it down, until it starts to look like a board-game â€” risk or something. And now you've reached the point where you can interact with all the 4X systems, but in very simplified way, and without overhead. And the game-design reached the point, where min-maxing it is more like a puzzle.

There are scripted events to which you have to prepare, and there are randomized smaller events.

You have income, expenses, and workers. You assign workers to tiles with different income types, and try to go into proficit. You need to often check the values on the tiles, because they change depending on the scripted and unscripted events.

There are "barbarian" settlements, with which you can trade, or you can annex them through piece or war.

The game ends when you reach victory conditions or when you run out of time.

It's simplistic with it's board-game graphics, but the worker animations are really good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968506604', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1705268194}
review: Compared to Old Kingdom, this was a lot worse experience in terms of pacing and balancing. You can be a hardcore strategy player, but any of you will with 90% certainty fail the challenges and trials the game throws at you. In fairness, as an egyptology-afficionado (I can basically translate hieroglyphs back and forth, I know grammar, honorary titles etc), there is a teachable effect to all the tribulations of the game. It teaches you the difficulties they faced. Though there are myriad other game modes that are less challenging, I picked the first "default" one that was meant as an "easy" game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997529945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1695741315}
review:
I'd give it a "so-so" if I could, as it really hasn't done anything bad and I got it as a gift, but as we live in a world run by binary algorithms...

It's a worker placement game. If you have ever played any board game ever, you've played this, as this is exclusively worker-placement. I have seen no other mechanics, and I never even really liked worker placement games. It does seem to have some real effort given to historical accuracy, but that does not translate into anything more developed than just flavor text for the assorted randomized events. 

I've seen some people liken this to Pharaoh and I couldn't disagree more. That game had lots more complexity, none the least because it had an entire additional layer of spatially concerned building systems that actually put the onus on you to design your city-states meaningfully, with foresight and a basic understanding of logistics and infrastructure. Roaming animals could actually wreck havoc on your settlement, kill citizens and necessitating immediate response on the part of your civil services (You -did- develop those, right?)  as opposed to simply penalizing your total generated number of resources per turn. Here you simply place the worker on the build box, hope you have enough workers placed to keep generating hammers, and you simply attain the bonuses. 

It's just kind of anemic, really. I suppose that's inevitable when you build your whole game around one of the most elementary tabletop board game designs. Usually you add something on top of that to give it some more complexity or personality but this is the extent of what you're getting. 

It's got a great thematic presentation and an undeniable understanding of the real history behind it's source material, but it just isn't all that engaging. It feels like a phone game, really- a pleasant time waster, but just a time waster. 

I just can't find myself endorsing that.

You will scout your land, put your slaves to work and kill other bastard tribes. Then you explore all of ancient egypt, kill  even more bastard tribes and put more slaves to work. While you are doing all of this you will learn all about the Ancient Kingdom and you shall hail the old Gods till time immoral!

Don't forget to put your slaves to work though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066623038', 'num_games_owned': 1745, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1691527909}
review:
It's not CIV. Thank god. 

Egypt Predynastic - has it's own nuance, stats, strategies, and things to learn. It feels fair, and the art style is perfect to capture Egypt. These are essential to making a fun game. Great job Clarus Victoria

author: {'steamid': '76561198127470967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1698430015}
review:
Easily worth the couple of quid it costs. Pretty to look at, engaging gameplay, and undemanding in terms of hardware. What's not to like?

Essentially a Civilisation game, but smaller in scale and obviously with the Egyptian theme. Quite challenging, but unless you're desperate to win all the 'trials' first time, there's still fun to be had, even if your city gets wiped out by a sandstorm...

author: {'steamid': '76561198042044934', 'num_games_owned': 2134, 'num_reviews': 336, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1690127297}
review:
[i] I want to preface this review with this: This is less a game and more a learning tool. It is very strict on rules, has very little replay value in terms of unique runs/campaigns, and constantly educates you on ancient Egypt. If you're looking for an actual strategy game where you need to adjust to your surroundings and you can go for different win conditions, this is not your game. If you want a very short game that is more-so a puzzle to figure out where things need to go, and when they need to be there, in a very strict time limit, then this is your game. [/i]

Pre-Dynastic Egypt is much more so a learning tool, and a puzzle game, than it is a strategy game. It has an incredibly strict turn timer, little to no variation in runs as it tries to stick to historical accuracy, and is entirely unforgiving. I'm not going to tell you it is bad, but I also won't argue that it was fun at any point.

I love starting with graphics as they are often the most striking part of a game's make-up, and Pre-Dynastic Egypt scratches a certain itch. It looks like it could've come out in the early 2000's, maybe as a flash game. Heck, this entire game could've been a flash game. Very simple graphics, with very few animations. This is not an insult, you're unlikely to mistake this game for any other from a glance and I'd say this is a good thing. Plus, the UI is very easy to read, except for the game notifications that show up on the sides of the screen.

The Audio is a little bad, with it being badly mixed. The background buzzing of the Savannah will often drown out any other sounds from the game. Individual sounds are often very simple, but also sound like they've been compressed one too many times, and there is a distinct lack of music tracks for the game.

The gameplay is again where I'll say this: This is a learning tool and a puzzle game, more so than a strategy game. You need to do two things: Explore the map, and build your civilization. You explore the map by putting your puzzle pieces, AKA workers, on an undiscovered tile. After a large amount of turns, they'll discover what is on that tile. If it is the correct tile for a building, you can begin working on that building if you also have the corresponding technology unlocked. You can't chose where to build things, the map is static between playthroughs so you'll always have the same city layout and you'll always build things in mostly the same order. If a tile is occupied by another tribe you have to either take the land by force or peaceful merge with them.

Speaking of it, combat is random. You have a set amount of troop that you've trained, and the enemy has their amount. As you fight, both sides lose troops slowly. Then, at set intervals random events will happen like "Our troops hesitate" which increases the rate at which allied troops die or "We attacked from an ambush" which increases the rate at which the enemy dies. If a side in severely outnumbered, this doesn't much matter but with the strict turn timers you don't have time to build up massive armies to decimate enemies.

Bring up the thing I've already said now, but the turn timer. There is a hard set turn timer of 220 turns. This cannot be changed. Even on the lowest difficulty, this turn timer makes it nearly impossible to have a chill and relaxing run of this game. Instead you have to follow a rigid path with an eye for the details in order to actual "win" the game. This is fine if you want that, but I prefer to have a more open and diverse way of winning my strategy games, with more variation and customization to the campaign. This game does not provide that.

A bit more unique to this game though is the actual historical facts. Despite the gameplay not being to my tastes, there is a reason for these mechanics even if it makes the game less fun. Every turn is a certain year in Egyptian history. Certain event and trials that you have to overcome are based on actual historical struggles and events of actual Egyptians. You'll get facts about their gods and buildings thrown at you in good amounts, and the progression of the game follow the Unification of Egypt. It's a fascinating subject, and I'll give the game points for it having this historical focus.

This is not a bad product. It is instead a bad strategy game, an excellent learning tool and a good puzzle game. If you can get it on sale, this isn't a bad way to spend 2-4 USD. For full price, I'd be a bit hesitant.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048005276', 'num_games_owned': 879, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 450, 'last_played': 1689631487}
review:
Not a bad game, but it tries to sell itself as a strategy game when it really is a puzzle game. Within the realm of game mechanics and harsh time restrictions, there isn't really much room for strategy as much as there is finding the single right order of steps to take in order to solve the puzzles it throws at you.

The biggest challenge is the game throwing seemingly random (although most of it's scripted) problems at you to solve, which can be extremely damaging on your first playthrough, and subsequently a breeze on later playthroughs since they happen at the same time every game.

The game does have its merits: there's some historical context tooltips sprinkled in the game as things happen around you, whether that be from researching technologies, constructing buildings, or just events. And the game has some cool ideas, like how you can't just stack soldiers indefinitely as they're always retiring from old age or how you can't communicate with neighboring tribes until you actually take steps to solidify your own state as a centralized nation. It just doesn't feel like it really does enough to capitalize on these - in an effort to make the game follow history as much as possible, there's very little actual player agency over the course of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198891492305', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 232, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1712318724}
review: An interesting and unique view of a part of egyptian history that is barely spoken of. The predynastic period is a really amazing, almost magical, where the foundations of the soon to be great civilization emerges, the early development of the culture and the unique view of the world by the natives gives a lot to think about. The game brings much of the feeling of discovery, each piece of new tech/culture unlocked, every settlement conquered, every construction, all of that transports you to this magical and beautiful period of civilization.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047974984', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1686736959}
review:
an excellent foray into focused historical strategy, though largely a puzzle, as opposed to a free flowing experience.  the enjoyment of the mid to early game is exceptional, as the gameplay is tight and rewards learning and planning.  the narrow margin for error is a downside, restricting the gameplay to a limited selection of defined historical paths, effectively making it a puzzle to find that path.
the ui could do with some work; my main gripe is the escape key starting battles in some menus.

The game is fascinating. 
It is a simple worker placement with its own depth. 
You can play through a campaign in about 3 to 4 hours. 
Surprisingly, it has a certain replayability and it fits thematically.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980443144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 9789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 533, 'playtime_at_review': 7909, 'last_played': 1711299153}
review:
Iâ€™m a big fan of this game. Iâ€™ve been playing this game on and off for over 5 years and have almost all the steam achievements. I have 130+ hours of gametime played. 

What do I like about this game; itâ€™s a virtual deck building card game without the mess of a set up on a physical table and much better graphics. Although there arenâ€™t that many variables to the game there are a few little surprises such as the variation in number of the opposing armies  or exactly where some of the tribes are hiding in the map. 

Itâ€™s a peaceful turn-based game where I can do house chores in between playing each turn, but there is enough interest to want to do well. Good game for those who are completer/finishers and like maths. A cute game, chill music vibe, and a game where you need to balance resources. Has a good list of well thought out achievements to obtain. 

Things that i think could make the game better - keyboard shortcuts!!! Switching between map, zooming, and ending turn

author: {'steamid': '76561197969062133', 'num_games_owned': 2114, 'num_reviews': 1251, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1669780265}
review: What at first appears to be a chill worker placement game about uniting ancient Egypt turns out to have aggravatingly difficult win conditions, exacerbated by being on track to succeed at a goal only for a random event or the extremely swingy combat to totally screw you over. If you have a lot of patience for strategy games you'll probably fare better than I did, but getting hosed out of a goal by a drought I couldn't have predicted really soured me on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165067989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1674803804}
review:
This game is fantastic. It's not only an easy-to-get-into turn-based strategy game, it also follows the *acutal history* of Egypt in a way that gives you lots of freedom to make your own decisions but also keeps a narrative going.

I learned a lot, had fun, didn't get all achievements so I'll replay it and had a great time.

review: è¿™æ˜¯ä¸ªå·®è¯„ã€‚è¿™æ˜¯ä¸ªå¾ˆæ¯›å­çš„æ¸¸æˆï¼Œä½†ä¸æ˜¯ä¸ªå¥½æ¸¸æˆã€‚å¸Œæœ›æ¯›å­ä»¥åæ”¹æ‰ç”¨æ¸¸æˆåšç§‘æ™®å¯¼è‡´æ¸¸æˆå¤ªç¡¬æ ¸çš„æ¯›ç—…ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ç©å®¶éœ€è¦åœ¨ç½‘ä¸Šæ‰¾ç‚¹å½¢å¼ä¸»ä¹‰çš„å¿«ä¹ã€‚ä»¥åŠï¼Œè°¢è°¢ï¼Œè¾›è‹¦äº†ã€‚

author: {'steamid': '76561197996406197', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 192, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 192, 'last_played': 1668388497}
review: The first part of the game is amazing.  I loved building up a city.  The turn to turn mechanics felt really satisfying.   However, as the game progresses, combat becomes increasingly central to your success.  The combat engine is deeply unpredictable, irrespective of the numerical advantage (or disadvantage) you may enter battle with.  Since numbers are the only measure of strength, this ends up feeling random and frustrating.  Outcomes for the same battle swinging from complete defeat (90% casualties) to complete victory (10% casualties) mean that effectively your results are a toss of the coin.  That is fairly historically accurate, but for a game in which you've invested hours and which is clearly expecting to be played like a game (i.e. there are victory conditions which crushing defeat will make impossible), it feels really bad.  If you like seeing cool, novel city building mechanics, I'd absolutely recommend the first part of this game.  But I found combat so arbitrary that finishing felt more like an exercise in save\load\retry than skill.  As such, I lost interest in finishing the game and that didn't feel great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021953887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 865, 'last_played': 1666619814}
review:
It had me staying awake last night, and I stopped playing other AAA games because of the enjoyment of playing Predynastic. It feels like a fresh mix of Caesar/Egypt city builders + Civilization city management gameplay, looking simple because of the graphics/aesthetics, but actually being a challenging resource management pazzle (at lease at my gamethrou that I choose the Historic difficulty settings). 
Just be prepared for The Great Drought challege: I had no idea that some of the de-buffs are applied permanently if you don't have the resources early on the challenge, and I am now really considering a fresh re-play.  :-)   
In overall, a really nice, kind-of-small game (Caesar and Civ are each a 200+ hours gameplay, while Predynastic will probably keep me occupied for a couple of runs, meaning about 30-40 hours). I feel my  money were well spend.

Edit: Finished the first playthrue in 20hrs gameplay (with interaptions from kids etc). The game has not so grand a plethora of alternative approaches, so I find myself moving into other games without starting a second playthrue (to try for achievments etc). So replayability is not even close to Caesar of Civ games. Nevertheless, I ebjoyed all these 20 hrs, and nowdays there are not many games that I still play till the end credits, so I really feel that purchasing Predynastic was warthing the money and time. :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198319999730', 'num_games_owned': 274, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1659489800}
review: If you like history and enjoy games about history, especially Ancient Egypt, then this game is for you! The game mechanics are fairly easy and I personally think it's quite a relaxing game, if you're not trying to achieve everything and get 100%. I find myself returning to this game once in a while to just have a chill session. Being a person who likes history and enjoys games about history, I like this game, because I don't know a lot about Ancient Egypt, therefore I can learn and relearn some facts about this particular period.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064492017', 'num_games_owned': 493, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1667064616}
review: Great and uniform art-style. Lightweight, simple to understand, and filled with just enough historical information about predynastic Egypt to keep an interested player engaged. Not replayable, unless you want to min-max, but definitely worth the coin (especially if you get it on sale). Looking forward to trying the second game. Refreshed my memory from textbooks, a solid 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046665598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1546, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1352, 'last_played': 1688477284}

author: {'steamid': '76561198242224246', 'num_games_owned': 29, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1657887587}
review:
This game is somehow eye candy, but I'm not sure that I want to recommend this game to others. Maybe if they're fans of Egypt, like me. Otherwise... The mechanics are somehow hard, the game lacks in explaining more clearly some features, like when the enemy attack, what to do, what to build, and so on.

For me was a joyful experience, although the game's AI beat me every time. Oh, and you can't set how easy the game you want to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980259241', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 201, 'last_played': 1656964198}
review:
Its a fun, solid little Civ-lite game, with straightforward mechanics introduced gradually throughout a session. The only mechanics that are a bit obtuse are the Trials that come up, but I think those are there to encourage replay...personally I don't see myself coming back to this one for awhile, and I beat it in the time shown played so far, so take that into account I suppose. I'm happy with my purchase, regardless.

7.5 / 10

review:
Learned more about Egypt from this game then school ever taught me.

Game-play is "basic"  but deep enough for a strategy fan to enjoy.  

So get it if you want to learn, or like a simple turn base game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997812576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 12526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 12, 'playtime_at_review': 8444, 'last_played': 1711247025}
review:
It is very much a worker-placement puzzle game, figuring out the optimal path to success -- unless you're playing easier setups which grant more leeway on how to proceed. Harder setups are HEAVILY dependent on RNG, including in random hidden setups which you won't discover until later in the game. So there isn't much point in trying for a 'gold' victory on harder setups, but aside from extra help rewards in progressing the game all it gives you is an end-screen rating. So I recommend playing on 'medium', or at worst 'historical' setup (which is challenging enough by itself) if not easy setups.

A pleasant colorful worker-placement strategy game otherwise, almost a boardgame design. The sequel (which starts elsewhere on the overmap about halfway through this game) has some upgraded mechanics. Both are worthy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144427989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 175, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1527939421}
review: As a history nerd I love this game. Pre-dynastic Egypt is so undercovered compared to the middle and late dynasties so getting to make it yourself is an immersive way to learn. However starting a civilisation is hard and I have failed a good few times in this. Yet I was always ready to jump back in and try again. The art does a good job of trying to recreate the world as they drew it. The gameplay is another case of easy to learn, hard to master. Overall I recommend this game for nerds!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052058217', 'num_games_owned': 3041, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 530, 'last_played': 1631536303}
review:
Probably the best Clarus Victoria so far. I really like its historical aspect as you explore the early beginnings of Egypt through set of events and tales, coupled with interesting background information on how people lived and developed back then. The game is not really replayble outside of achievement hunting and everything is pretty linear but the resource management is still enjoyable and constant challenges makes you wanna push that 'one more turn' button over and over again in curiosity.

If there is one flaw it's the difficulty settings which are better left untouched as otherwise it makes the game impossible and not fun (even on historical settings). But outside of that it's really nice trip back to the era where the civilization was born.

author: {'steamid': '76561198269338087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1627405073}
review:
A good game like any of Clarus Vctoria.

Maybe I'm wrong, but it seems to me that the randomization of allocating resources to the fields has been introduced, which spoils the fun on the highest difficulty levels (it does't matter  on the low level). I do not mind events of fate - I understand that sometimes you can be unlucky. However, if a given land was fertile in one game, and when I start the game all over again, it suddenly becomes barren, it is a bit pointless. Sometimes the allocation of one food point from a given field determines success.

review: I cannot recommend this game. It is overly simplistic, not particularly fun, and the only â€œchallengeâ€ comes in the form of a resource race against the clock. If you must get it, wait for a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067116236', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1624085328}
review: Predynastic Egypt is fun. It has an interesting and appealing indie style. The gameplay is solid. I encountered no bugs. The way the game progresses is very linear which dims replayability. I played it twice and enjoyed both playthroughs, but that's enough for now. Recommended for anyone who likes ancient Egyptian history, likes egypt, casual nation-building (if you can call it that) and has <10 Euros to spend instead of going to see a movie or something. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198014881208', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1621673559}
review: What a delightful little game. Lovely artwork and interesting background information on ancient Egypt. Intuitive game-play that is explained reasonably well (not quite perfectly: I had to Google for a few things). Very varied and thematic difficulty settings provide some replayability. Fully turn-based, with manual saves. A full play-through took me about 3â€“4 hours, though I like to take my time and read everything. I bought this on sale for Â£1.74 (roughly US$2.50). Firm recommend if you like gentle turn-based strategy games with plenty of learning opportunities.

review: Die Idee an sich find ich gut, leider ist das Spiel so aufgebaut, dass in den 220 Runden die man Zeit hat das Alte Ã„gypten aufzubauen, einem "Fehler" aus z.B. Beispiel: Gleich am Anfang gibt es ein Zufallsevent mit Schakalen. Geht dieses Negativ fÃ¼r den Spieler aus (Chance 50-50, wird ausgewÃ¼rfelt), fresse die Schakale die VorrÃ¤te (2 Getreide). Das sorgt dafÃ¼r, dass der nÃ¤chste Arbeiter erst 2 Runden spÃ¤ter gebaut werden kann. 2 Runden weniger Produktion sind 4 Nahrung weniger, was fÃ¼r eine VerzÃ¶gerung beim nÃ¤chsten Arbeiter sorgt usw. Dieser Rattenschwanz zieht sich dann bis ans Ende durch, nur weil man in Runde 3 WÃ¼rfelpech hatte, man also noch nicht einmal was dafÃ¼r konnte. Das ganze gleicht eher einem Puzzel als einem Spiel, schafft man es die richtigen Zugreinfolgen zu finden, spielt sich jeder Durchgang gleich, regelmÃ¤ÃŸiges Speichern vor wichtigen Zufallsevents die man nach einer Zeit kennt ist Pflicht, ab da spielt sich das Spiel wie auf Schienen. review:
Easy to learn, hard to master. Including a lot of things to think about... I mean about old Egypt...
Functional crossover between turn-based strategy and history lesson.

Everybody who is interested in ancient Egypt can add few more points to final rating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039671407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 547, 'last_played': 1619909469}
review:
Obviously I bought this because I dreamed of being Indiana Jones as a kid, an archeologist specializing in Egyptology.

This game is really fun and reminds me a bit of civilization in a more simplified form. I've thoroughly enjoyed it.

I did find a lot of english typo's but nothing that blocks the game or makes it unplayable. Did not encounter any bug.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011534887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2737, 'last_played': 1618397897}
review:
Eccoci con un altro bell'indie!
Come molti non mi sento di suggerirlo a prezzo pieno, rifacendo la campagna completa 4/5 volte (per cercare di fare punteggi migliori) ci ho giocato ~20 ore.

Tuttavia Ã¨ un bel gestionale, a sfide crescenti, che sono una sorta di Check di evoluzione.
Siete una sorta di capotribÃ¹, che deve dislocare la varia manodopera a svolgere diversi compiti: esplorare nuove aree, raccogliere cibo. PiÃ¹ progredite piÃ¹ si svilupperanno nuove mansioni.
Per verificare che stiate evolvendo bene, il gioco vi darÃ  delle prove (scriptate) che prima e meglio supererete, maggiori saranno le ricompense. 

Mi Ã¨ piaciuto molto lo stile e la scelta grafica molto evocativa, ma l'intera interfaccia risulta semplice e molto immediata.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025675343', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1336, 'last_played': 1619995859}
review:
Do you like history? Do you like Egypt? Do you like strategy crossed with board game mechanics? Then you need to play this.

Predynastic Egypt is a strategy Tabletop-Game-like History simulator created by people who know what they're doing. The game covers the entire history of Ancient Egypt from its early beginnings to the First Pharaohs with a serious dedication to both challenge and historical accuracy, which greatly please this Ancient Egyptian History nerd. I got it solely for that reason, and soon discovered a challenging but fun and replayable game. And I do mean challenging, this game [i]will[/i] take you multiple tries and several hours to  beat the first time, on easy mode. That's not even counting optimizations for finishing the game faster, going for achievements, and learning what best makes the game tick. You really can't waste time either, unless you're going for certain achievements just focus on winning the game first and trying out strategy later. There's also a bit of a luck component to it, so be aware of that - but changing the difficulty can certainly help out in that department. Protip, I wouldn't try setting everything to hard for certain achievements unless you've played several times already, just do them one at a time.

I didn't really have that many issues with this game - no glitches even, it's remarkably well polished for what it is. The one issue may be that it's just a bit too difficult for some players, even on the easy mode. I thrive on hard and hardcore games myself, and this one was challenging even to me. I don't doubt it would have most speedrunners pulling their hair out in frustration too. But once you figure out what the game wants you to do in what order, it's not terribly difficult. That brings up a new issue though - the game slightly railroads you if you want to succeed. You don't [i]have[/i] to trade with everyone... but you probably should. You don't [i]have[/i] to prioritize certain things... unless you want to win. Congrats, you won, now do it all again in the same order but do it better this time. That's a bit of the nature of the beast, however; the point of the game is to min-max to the extreme until you have it all down pat. One final nitpick is that there are some grammatical errors in the game especially pertaining to god names, possibly because the creators aren't native English speakers - you'll see stuff like "The Horus" or "The Seth" despite the fact that neither of these gods would have been referred to like that and gods like Wepwawet are named properly. Also, might bug the history junkies here to see Set written as Seth, but these are nitpicks.

I highly recommend this game to strategy buffs, Egyptian history geeks, and competitive-minded people, but due to the challenge I'm not certain it's for everyone. I think you'll know if this style of game appeals to you or not based on a few play-throughs. I didn't think I'd like it as much as I did, but I really had fun with it and have sunk more hours into this than into Valheim or any of the more recent games in my collection, proof positive that simplicity is honestly the best policy sometimes. I can't wait until I get bored with this game or get all the cheevos so I can play Egypt: Old Kingdom!

author: {'steamid': '76561198344904307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1614290411}
review: My first impression of the game: Predynastic Egypt from Clarus Victoria was that it is a typical mobile game city building game. Here you have a house, a farmer. Next step, a metropolis of millions. Not really. You play with cards on a board game-like terrain. The setting is the upper and lower part of the Nile Delta in the ancient pre-Egyptian stage. You have to complete various quests, build temples and keep the economy going. The historical context is kept realistic and, like Age of Empires 1, there are always little texts with real references to the story. It is a pretty good and balanced turn-based strategy game. The purchase was worth it and for the fact that I only wanted to test it "briefly", I played a four-hour round. Good entertainment for a fair price. I could really imagine the game as a board game, should the developers read this entry. The artwork and game design should transfer very well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064315577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1614214231}
review:
Ich habe das Spiel noch nicht durch, aber finde es persÃ¶nlich bislang relativ gut (fÃ¼r den Anfang).
Es ist auf das Wesentliche reduziert (soweit ich das beurteilen kann, bin ja kein Ã„gyptologe).

Die Grafik und UI ist relativ einfach gehalten, aber weder kitschig noch zu abstrakt:
+ Technologiebaum
+ Ereignisse
+ Religion und Kulturentwicklungsbaum
+ Karte mit Ressourcen und fremden StÃ¤mmen von Ã„gypten und der Siedlung auf denen man die Arbeiter verschiebt

Die Beziehung von Religionen / Kulten und konkrete Auswirkungen auf Ressourcen macht das Spiel vielleicht abwechslungsreicher, aber auch weniger "glaubwÃ¼rdig" im Sinne von Aberglauben. Alternativ hÃ¤tte man hier vielleicht auch "realistische" Machtstrukturen / Politik / Sozialstrukturen / Religionssoziologie / Bildung / Gesundheit / AbhÃ¤ngigkeitsverhÃ¤ltnisse etc. einbauen kÃ¶nnen, welche das damals genau waren und wie man sowas (einfach) umsetzen kÃ¶nnte, da bin ich allerdings mit meinen Kenntnissen Ã¼berfragt. Vermutlich wÃ¼rde sowas auch den Rahmen eines solchen Spiels Ã¼bersteigen. Zumindest regt dieses Spiel hier auch an, sich mit den Kulten weiter zu beschÃ¤ftigen.

Die Spieldauer scheint sich auch im Rahmen zu halten, so dass es bislang nicht ausufert. Es gibt ja auch noch anderen MÃ¶glichkeiten sich mit der Ã¤gyptischen Geschichte zu beschÃ¤ftigen, seien es BÃ¼cher, Filme oder andere (Computer-)spiele, Z.B. StÃ¤dtebauspiele oder Assassins Creed Discovery Tour. Den zweiten Teil von dem Spiel habe ich ja auch noch.

Man kann ja auch wÃ¼nschen, dass die unzÃ¤hligen staatlich finanzierten Institutionen, ihre historische Forschung Ã¶ffentlich im Internet machen, also praktisch und einfach mit Webseiten, die miteinander verlinkt sind oder ganz futuristisch mit Confluence z.B., oder besser noch, auch diese Lehrmittel / Spiele / Filme zu finanzieren und zu verlinken. Das die Lehrmittel dann sogar immer auf dem aktuellen Stand der Forschung wÃ¤ren. So dass man hier auf solider Grundlage stehen wÃ¼rde. So dass jeder BÃ¼rger etwa auch den aktuellen Stand wÃ¼sste.

Also etwa sowas Ã„hnliches wie etwa Microsoft Encarta vor 20 Jahren. Staatlich finanziert im Internet, anstatt in irgendwelchen Spezialbibliotheken zu verstauben. Aber gut, dass wÃ¤re natÃ¼rlich im Jahr 2021 wirklich zuviel verlangt...

Oder staatlich subventioniert im Abomodell? So dass z.B. der Forscher, der seine Lehrmaterialien auf dem aktuellen Stand hÃ¤lt, auch daran gemessen wird, etwa?

author: {'steamid': '76561198872147873', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1612107985}
review:
4.5/5

A very decent Civilization-like game with nice design and interesting historical details.

I finished the game twice with easy settings, it lasts 3-4 hours at a calm pace. The gameplay keeps you focused, you don't get bored until the third playthrough, but from then the mechanics feel repetitive.

I really liked the informational details about the development of Ancient Egypt, I learned some new moments from the history of Egyptian tribes. It is really felt that professional historians were involved in the creation. Also, I was pleased to see some arts showing what the ancient tribes looked like, according to the modern science.

I recommend it to everyone interested in the history of Egypt, the game is worth a try.

Interested to try out the next game in the series!

author: {'steamid': '76561197989757947', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 377, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1609728354}
review:
While one might be tempted to compare this to the classic city builder Pharaoh, don't. That's not what this is.
Predynastic Egypt is a fast paced addictive board game that is more focused on completing a list of challenges as fast and as efficiently as possible. There are city builder elements, but it's better to think of this as a virtual board game than as a typical city builder.

It does what it does, and it does it very very well. I think the only compliant is that once you've mastered it, there's nothing that brings you back. Good luck getting gold rank on everything on hard, though.
9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198033384068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1629609647}
review:
Played through once just now, and it was a fun 5 hours of gameplay.  Don't think I'm going to play through again (not that replayable), but well worth the $5 or so I spent on it.  I'd give it a 6.5 out of 10, probably worth about $15 to me.

It seemed pretty well balanced, and it was a good looking game.  It changes things up giving you fun challenges and the feeling of the dynamics of your kingdom changing as it expands.  Just overall a pretty fun game.

That said before you play realize that the win conditions are as follows:  by turn 220, you need 5k food, to build an EXPENSIVE building (like 700 a turn for I think it was 10 turns), to conquer most of Egypt, and most of all you need to research something worth 45000!  I'm a little salty because by the time the Unification of Egypt challenge appeared it was too late.  Admittedly, I THINK that they told me what was required in the beginning, and they help out some through periodic random boons.

I also would have liked an automanage mode for distributing your workers between the areas because when you get up to 50 or so it's either a pain to micromanage or you give up on maximizing efficiency.

Last gripe is that while I got the impression that they really knew their stuff when it came to ancient Egypt, you don't really get to see much micro detail (how their technology worked, what life was like, etc).  It's more macro details like gods, kings, ideas, etc.  But some of those portraits were cool (Seth and Horus especially).

But don't let any of that hold you back.  The end goals are doable, managing workers in the end isn't too bad, and you do get a pretty good look at Egyptian culture.  So if you like Egypt, the Bronze Age, or this type of game in general then go ahead and get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108685912', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 279, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1609279972}
review:
Like the Artwork. Game play is mixed. Mechanics are fairly simple in that you've a limited number of workers and several different tasks to employ them on. So you end up shuffling workers around, and saving up for the next thing that's stopping you progressing because you have to do that. 
And just when you get into the swing of that you are attacked by the mushroom people or whatever who don't look that powerful but beat you in an auto resolved combat. Now you can rebuild after that or you can uninstall the game and request a refund. 
Even on Sale I wouldn't bother.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996513982', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1609106072}
review:
This is a fantastic game. 

The basic idea is to play through 220 turns during which you have to build up the food, production, military and cultural strength of a nascent Ancient Egypt as it begins the process of unifying as a single Kingdom. As well as managing and building up your settlement, you have to react to various events which can further sap your resources, and you ideally need to plan ahead and build up a decent stockpile of resources, while at the same time spending enough to upgrade and grow your settlement and ensuring you are doing enough research and development to work up the basic tech tree (it's split - *very* broadly- into 3 branches that help you with boosting food and production, improving governance and political control over the developing culture, and religious and cultural philosophies.

How it actually plays is very much in the vein of a worker placement Euro Boardgame, and doing so allows you to either extract resources from the zone or otherwise interact with it - draw food production form fields, industry production from quarries, scout unexplored terrain, trade with or attack other tribes etc). 

I have only had one play through so far ( I failed, but didn't do too badly) using the "historical" start options (you can choose from a variety of options that can make the game easier or harder but give you bonus score at the end). It took me around 3 hours to play the 220 turns which I think is pretty good for the first time I've played it but I am big boardgamer so that might have helped. I also think familiarity with the game might help and it definitely bears replayability I think. 

Overall I am delighted with this - I got it on sale and was expecting something maybe akin to Pharoah (a game I absolutely love) from the citybuilding line (Caesar, Zeus, Emperor) so to get essentially a solo Euro Boardgame with an Ancient Egyptian theme is a very pleasant surprise. I look forward to playing this more, and getting the sequel which moves the timeline forward. 
I would recommend this to anyone who wants something a bit different and certainly to anyone who likes boardgames, particularly that certain type of solo boardgames that are (at heart) efficiency simulators against a time limit.
The graphics, while somewhat tilted towards the functional end of the spectrum, are still very pretty and evocative of the theme and do exactly what they need to do while still being interesting and nice to look at. The sound is probably the weakest area - which is not to say it is bad by any means, it's just don't go expecting a sweeping orchestral score. But then again it arguably doesn't need it, and the clang of swords that accompany the battle outcome screen and the sawing of would and hammering that accompanies a built facility do their job more than adequately. Combat is essentially a numbers game, with certain buffs and choices manipulating the base numbers by a certain percentage or occasionally raw number (a blessing of a god might reduce enemy numbers by 10 percent for example, or a one time boost from a trade might give you x amount of extra soldiers). It's very simple - don't go expecting total war battles or anythig like that. But again, it doesn't need to be and the way it works is very suitable for the board game-esque theme - it's not about simulating battles or being a general, it's literally did you efficiently plan ahead to have enough soldiers to get through the battles you need to.

So overall - I recommend this game. I *heavily* recommend this game if:
You like boardgames (esp. solo boardgames)
You like planning and maximising efficiency and worker placement.
You can overlook a game that doesn't have triple A polish and bells and whistles in favour of satisfying core mechanics

I would *not* recommend this(or at least suggest you look into it further) if:
You hate boardgames
You don't like turnbased gamed
The theme does nothing for you
You need deep and strategic combat
You don't like it being possible for you to mismanage a game to the point it is impossible (or near as dammit) to pull back from the state you've gotten yourself into.

More games like this I say

author: {'steamid': '76561198329062552', 'num_games_owned': 42, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2920, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 620, 'last_played': 1611368761}
review:
El Primer juego de la saga Egypt de Clarus Victoria, Predynastic Egypt nos lleva a los meros principios de una de las man antiguas civilizaciones del mundo, bajo una presentacion vistosa y colorida, y con informacion bien investigada.

Con un gameplay particular similar a juegos de mesa, y a las entregas de otras sagas de estrategia como Civilization, el juego puede parecer simple a primera vista, sin embargo, detrÃ¡s de el se encuentra una dificultad disfrutable, de la cual requerirÃ¡ toda la planeaciÃ³n de uno para lograr superar los retos y desafÃ­os del juego con el mayor puntaje posible.

Si bien el juego en si es muy lineal en comparaciÃ³n con su secuela, sin muchos elementos variables entre diferentes partidas, (Mas alla de eventos aleatorios algo molestos), asi como algo corto, para lo que es, lo considero como puntos negativos menores en comparasion con todo lo demas.

Para todos los amantes de la historia del Egipto antiguo, asi como para todos aquellos que disfrutan de los juegos de estrategia por turnos y seguidores de Clarus Victoria, les recomiendo de todo corazon este titulo, y apoyen a los desarrolladores.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070926151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1609080529}
review:
This game is quick to finish and you found the game is easy. 
However, the real challenge arises from mastering efficient resource allocation - which happens when you replay the game.

With some practice, you can enhance the efficiency of your resource allocation. 
At the same time, there is RNG events disrupting your plan and needs to modify the plan to achieve higher final score.

In a nutshell, this can be a decent choice if,
a) the price is right(at least 70% on sale),
b) you like relatively simplified logic of tech tree,
c) you are willing to end the game multiple times

author: {'steamid': '76561198021434988', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 4619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2914, 'last_played': 1613269113}
review:
A very good immersive historic turn-based game sequencing events of 5000BC to 3000BC in Egypt.
If you're into turn-based games that include some history, you will not regret it.
Think like an egyptian :)
Only negative - It doesn't have endless replayability like 4x games, but still has a lot of replayability.

It does make you appreciate how some little things in life changed history..
Thank you donkeys for carrying our stuff :) And Kudos to the inventor of the plow.

Late advise to early egyptians : Think a little less about tombs and gods!!

author: {'steamid': '76561197999470590', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 545, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 545, 'last_played': 1606259180}
review:
This is about as basic a Civ game as you could imagine.  But as I did complete it without getting bored, it scrapes a thumbs up.  I am not convinced it has much educational value, just as civ doesn't really teach you why the rule of law was important, or what the temple of Artemis was. You just look at the advantages of each development and don't spare much thought for the logic, if there is any.  

Don't be put off by the complaints that it is difficult. It does require thought but it's easier than the mainstream civ games.

review: This is a fun little game that can teach a lot about ancient Egypt specifically and the process of state formation. I see many of these reviews are dinging it for low replay value -- while this is certainly true for adults, I think this is an excellent game for children.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132995625', 'num_games_owned': 1414, 'num_reviews': 754, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1606791723}
review:
[h1]Predynastic Egypt[/h1]
Historische Simulation von 2016.
1800tes Game in meinem Archiv.

Mache dich bereit, evolutionÃ¤re DurchbrÃ¼che zu erzielen, welche es den alten Ã„gyptern ermÃ¶glichten in ferne LÃ¤nder einzumarschieren, Herausforderungen und Katastrophen zu Ã¼berstehen und letztendlich den ersten Ã¤gyptischen Staat zu grÃ¼nden. Wirst du in der Lage sein die echten historischen Ereignisse nachzuspielen oder wirst du deinen aufstrebenden Stamm in die vergessenen Kapitel der Geschichte verdammen? Erlange durch dieses einzigartige Spiel detaillierte Kenntnisse Ã¼ber das, was vor der klassischen Ã¤gyptischen Ã„ra geschah.
(Entwickler)

Na das ist doch mal eine gut gelungene Simulation des alten Niltales und seiner Kultur.

Da ich Egypt: Old Kingdom schon gespielt habe, war ich gespannt darauf wie denn dieses Spiel wohl ist. Alles Beginnt damit das du mehre MÃ¶glichkeiten hast das Spiel zu Starten in dem du deine zukÃ¼nftige Regierungsrichtung voreinstellst. Du hast verschiedene MÃ¶glichkeiten dieses Spiel zu starten, von Historisch bis Ahistorisch.  

Ich habe die Historische Kampagne gewÃ¤hlt und muÃŸte Feststellen das es schwerer ist wie der Nachfolger. Das Gameplay ist anders, etwas linearer und mit mehr militÃ¤rischen aktionen.
Wie auch der Nachfolger wird hier sehr viel Wert gelegt auf historische
Ereignisse und Aufgaben. 
Ein ganz gutes Spiel. Eine deutliche Empfehlung von mir.

Deine Aufgabe ist simpel. Erweiter dein Einflussgebiet, unterwerfe alle anderen StÃ¤mme auf die du triffst, verehre die GÃ¶tter und mache die Bewohner im Reich des Pharao satt und glÃ¼cklich. 
Versorge diese Weltregion mit allem was sie braucht um erfolgreich zu sein.
Ein tolles Spiel. Eine Empfehlung von mir.

[h1] Predynastic Egypt [/h1]
Historical simulation from 2016.
1800th game in my archive.

Get ready to achieve evolutionary breakthroughs that enabled the ancient Egyptians to invade distant lands, weather challenges and disasters and ultimately establish the first Egyptian state. Will you be able to re-enact the real historical events, or will you condemn your aspiring tribe into the forgotten chapters of history? Gain detailed knowledge of what happened before the classical Egyptian era through this unique game.
(Developer)

Well, that's a well done simulation of the old Nile valley and its culture.

Since I've already played Egypt: Old Kingdom, I was excited to see how this game would be. It all starts with the fact that you have more options to start the game by setting your future government direction. You have different options to start this game, from historical to ahistorical.

I chose the historical campaign and had to realize that it is harder than the successor. The gameplay is different, a little more linear and with more military action.
Like the successor, a lot of emphasis is placed on historical ones
Events and tasks.
Quite a good game. A clear recommendation from me.

Your job is simple. Expand your area of â€‹â€‹influence, subjugate all other tribes you meet, worship the gods and make the inhabitants of the pharaoh's realm satisfied and happy.
Provide this world region with everything it needs to be successful.
A great game. A recommendation from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014884945', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1604519036}
review:
Juego de estrategia por turnos, una campaÃ±a cerrada en la que evolucionas una tribu hasta controlar todo el antiguo Egipto en solitario, luchando o uniÃ©ndote a otras tribus. Hay un lÃ­mite de turnos, y debes gestionar todo el avance dando labores a cada ciudadano para obtener los otros recursos: trigo - crecimiento; herramientas - construcciÃ³n; armas - ejÃ©rcito; avalorios - cultura; emblemas - favores divinos. Los eventos, las misiones y la contrarreloj te pondrÃ¡n en aprietos mÃ¡s de una vez en cada partida! A pesar de su aparente simplicidad, no creas que vas a alcanzar el Ã©xito en tu primera partida.

Creo que los desarrolladores se plantearon un reto: "queremos hacer un juego fÃ¡cil de explicar, fÃ¡cil de entender y de manejar, casi sin animaciÃ³n, pero con decisiones estratÃ©gicas de complejidad creciente y un poco de generaciÃ³n aleatoria. para impedir al jugador echarse una partida rÃ¡pida exitosa."

-si te gusta el genero te engancharÃ¡

author: {'steamid': '76561198000845028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1593655072}
review: I've always enjoyed strategy/Civilization-like games and can generally do well in terms of gameplay, goals, and victory conditions.  I've played this game at least twice and have no idea what kind of strategy might be effective.  I've never gotten particularly close to completing all the victory conditions, and I have no idea why not.  I looked at a game guide, and it appears that you need to memorize a set pattern of choices and then follow the script to achieve victory.  That does not hold much appeal for me.  Additionally, the language of this game feels awkward in English.

review: Es el primer juego al que le dedico una reseÃ±a, asÃ­ que quizÃ¡s no tenga la calidad de otras que se puedan encontrar por aquÃ­, pero me parecÃ­a injusto pasar sin dedicarle unas palabras de agradecimiento a los desarrolladores del juego. Lo he disfrutado muchÃ­simo. Ya no por la idea y mecÃ¡nicas, que pese a ser sencillas me han encantado; sino por el gran cariÃ±o que se nota que han dedicado en la creaciÃ³n de este juego. Las ilustraciones, la mÃºsica y especialmente las anotaciones histÃ³ricas que nos brinda el juego nos ayudan a sumergirnos en el antiguo Egipto como nunca antes habÃ­a podido experimentar y que ni de lejos esperaba encontrar al ver por primera vez la sencillita interfaz del juego al arrancarlo. Sinceramente, muchas gracias por tantas horas de diversiÃ³n y por esta pequeÃ±ita obra de arte que habÃ©is creado. Juegos como este son los que me siguen haciendo adorar esta industria y bucear en la tienda de steam durante horas con la esperanza de encontrar un nuevo gran juego al que guardar cariÃ±o. De todo corazÃ³n, gracias.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124275446', 'num_games_owned': 1852, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1599873021}
review:
[h1]***WARNING: This is a mixed review.***[/h1]

Predynastic Egypt is touted as a strategy/simulation/city-builder on its store page, which are all tags I frequently buy. I also adore ancient Egypt and support most games that feature even a single level inspired by the time period (I'm looking at you, Serious Sam!). It's a no brainer that I would buy this game, then. As obvious as it seems that I would love this, the game fell short in many ways.

First: the game is $9.99. I doubt I bought it for that price, but since I go by the $1.00 per hour rule of gameplay (minimum), I would wait for a severe sale on this. (60% or more off.) My 3.6 hour gameplay includes two playthroughs of the game. Yes, two playthroughs of the [i]entire game[/i]. See, Predynastic Egypt doesn't feature scenarios, a lengthy campaign, or even creative freedom of any sense. It is, in its entirety, one linear level in which you lead your ancient Egyptians from a tiny tribe to a city with whole armies. Everything works well enough and I experienced no glitches. The aesthetic of the game is attractive, if simplified; workers and armies show up like hieroglyphs on a "card" in their location rather than 3D models. It is reminiscent of a grand strategy map with no real-time battles; battles are fought as a numbers game on a separate window that pops up when applicable. That isn't to say this part of the game is [i]bad[/i], just...[i]simple.[/i] Everything about this game screams simple and surface-level.

Thus, I would have been likely to recommend this game if it weren't for the caveat of the stringent rules it puts in place for you. Not only does the game offer just one "level," it severely limits what you can do, when you can do it, and what order you need to do it in. I have a severe aversion to a lack of freedom in any game; time limits and other such strings deplete my enjoyment greatly, and this game has that and more. For example, it basically wants you to unite Egypt in 200 turns. That may sound easy for such a simplified game, and once you've gone through a playthrough you might think you know the game well enough to have a shot at it. That's how I felt. But even though I knew how things worked, because of the linearity of everything from the research trees to the mandatory challenges, I found it hard to get a better score or unite within the 200 turns because I had no freedom of strategy. I love strategy games because you can try so many strategies, learn from your mistakes, and win using smart tactics (or even better, find new strategies by trial-and-error before replicating them in other games to see if they work). Here, you can't try anything new. Because if you do "insert action here", then you'll fail this mandatory challenge, which will lead to resource depletion as a negative consequence, which will undermine your future actions. Additionally, even if you try to hit the objectives, failing just one can lead to subsequent failings because the challenge was a prerequisite. Believe it or not, I ended up doing [i]worse[/i] in my second playthrough because I was trying new strategies and getting punished for it, whereas during my first playthrough I followed things by the letter and got a better score. 

In this sense, Predynastic Egypt feels more like an hour and a half long tutorial for a game you never get to play. I enjoyed most of my time with the game, because it runs well, is aesthetically attractive, and can be relaxing for a simulation/strategy game. But it quickly turns frustrating and hopeless, because you know that no matter what you do, your experience will remain the same. There is no reason to replay it when the timing and objectives never change. If the developer ever released an update where it adds other scenarios, maps, or a freedom-to-build mode, I would be far less harsh on the game. Until then, I have to say I don't recommend this game. Casual players will only get an hour or two out of it, while seasoned veterans of strategy-sims like me will probably get only double that because they will refuse to believe there isn't something they can do to change their experience in subsequent playthroughs. I do not [i]hate[/i] this game; I just find it extraordinarily unremarkable, and there are far better games deserving of a player's time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157527775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 785, 'last_played': 1651793785}
review:
My momentary situation is a sad one, my notebook can barely run any games. :( So I began my quest to find games that it can run and that I can enjoy. This has to be one of the most enjoyable games! If you're a bit of a nerd and maybe a fan euro style boardgames with lots of strategic worker placement: this is your game! I also enjoy the look of it, which also reminds me of euro style board games.
I came because of my desparation and stayed because of the fun! Wheeeee! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198088213774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 110, 'last_played': 1593501826}
review:
This game is odd. 

I bought it because I liked Marble Age - by the same developers. 

Where Marble Age is a fantastic, difficult, balancing strategy game, this one is more of just a grind. involving manually reallocating single workers. 

The rules are unclear on the second half. 

I got the game for $3 on the Steam sale, so whatevs, certainly at that price don't hesitate to buy the game.
developer_response: Hello spots2012! Why you did not recomend our game to other people? Only because you think what our game odd? You played Predynastic egypt only one time and just don't have a much time to realize what this game is difficuld and balanced strategy game too! Please try more and maybe it will change your mind about that!

author: {'steamid': '76561198031725194', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1593264957}
review:
Eeeeeeh. I thoroughly enjoyed my time with the game, but it didn't satisfy me at all as I finished it.

This is like a super-competent flash game more than a real strategy game. Plus it has a really cool historical component.

The problem I have with the game is that it is mostly about event rather than systems. Many of the game's challenges change important variables simply as a way of creating artificial barriers to fit historical timelines. For example, in the last stretch of the unification of Egypt, where you subdue the last tribes, they are too powerful for you. It's unreasonable for you to fight them, almost impossible with the game's balance up to that point. Once you gain the quest to unite the last tribes, though, you gain a bonus that makes them much weaker than before. So now you can go and subdue them with the same army you had before.
Most of the game's events are like this. The "routine" management and strategy aspects aren't very deep, and when a major event needs to happen (with roughly the same timeline as real history), the game changes its rules.

The strategy aspect then suffers a lot, since you can't plan very well, unless you have played the game before and know what is going to happen and when.

I have only played the game on "easy" mode (the game offers different modifiers when you start the game, and I chose the recommended settings for beginners), but not "extra easy" mode, which the game offers halfway through. There are two higher difficulties which I am sure are more challenging - but this challenge has more to do with foreknowledge than with mechanical mastery.

I often think of Europa Universalis for historical dynamics done right. In that game, many mechanics also act as barriers, but behave as systems rather than timed gates controlled by the developers. The best example was the Casus Beli. You can't start a war if you don't have a cause. This is the mechanic, and it reflects history to some extent - in geopolitics, you can't just attack everyone like a madman without expecting other countries to promptly eliminate you; there are social/moral norms applied to politics within the european states. To declare a war, then, you can use causes like "I held this  province 10 years ago and I want to reclaim it", or use marriage ties. Furthermore, you can also use spies to forge claims, which may succeed, or fail and give you a reputation hit among other states. 
You learn the historical dynamics by understanding what you can and cannot do, and then everyone plays by the same rules. It's a "simulation".

This game isn't a simulation. The other tribes don't have the same variables as you have. There isn't much simulation, here. What there is is a relatively fixed sequence of events between which you have some degree of control, but not much.

The whole game is kind of a min-max race. And early mistakes can have big costs later on, since the game plays like a snowball.

Other than that, the only criticism I have is that the research trees (building and research) are a bit too abstract. Even though you are following a historical sequence (like building Scorpion's or Narmer's tomb, the Temple of the Sun, discovering slavery, taxation, and so on) the way choices are presented make them too abstract. It all boils down to which number you want to increase right now. I haven't even read the name of the chosen research half of the time, all that mattered was the stats associated.
This is a problem when a game is so focused on the historical particulars as Predynastic Egypt is. Despite being historical, the information that actually matters in the players' heads become abstract and ahistorical in a self-defeating way.


That said, I can give a mild recommendation. I enjoyed my time with it. Although it has very limited replayability (unless you want to optimize a more or less fixed sequence of events), the presentation is great and it does make an attempt to present an accurate historical game, which I'd like to see more of. 
Of course, it's always a balance between history and playability, but it's good that they are trying to explore the often neglected side!
It's also cheap, so it can be a good palate-cleanser between meatier games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198796474147', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1546667274}
review:
Juego de recursos y exploracion.

Para quienes tienen una debilidad por la cultura egipcia se van a encontrar con un juego que los dejara mas que satisfechos. Para el resto sera un buen juego para aprender algunos cosas de la cultura egipcia, ya que el juego empieza desde el principio de esa civilizacion y con el tiempo va ir evolucionando con los adelantos que hizo esa gente. Cuando te presentan los adelantos te escriben una descripcion cortita de como lo hicieron o como lo usaron, algo muy interesante.

Respecto al juego es uno donde tenes que tener los recursos necesarios para ir creciendo tu civilizacion. Recolectando de varios tipos, ya sea comida, piedras e incluso cultura. Para quien tiene manejo de este tipo de juegos no creo que le cueste mucho pasar el juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079870399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 408, 'last_played': 1677329978}
review:
Predynastic Egypt is a fairly simple worker-placement game about guiding a population from having just settled to unifying Egypt under one king. It's turn-based, with an ultimate objective to accomplish certain goals by the end of Turn 220. During those turns, you will need to juggle managing several resources (food, production, military, culture, authority, and worker limit) to progress towards these goals as well as exploring the map. While the game has progressions of buildings and technologies, they are very linear and the strategy is mostly about which to get and in what order. Instead, most of the gameplay is about where to place your workers to accomplish your ends.

The turn limit is pretty tight, and you will likely not accomplish your objectives until the final turns (if you do at all). My experience has been that it takes about 2 hours to play through the full 220 turns. When you hit the time limit, the game allows you to keep playing (win or lose) if you like. That said, the turn limit makes a nice "opponent" for the game, and I found it difficult enough to be quite satisfying.

I would say that the game feels more like a puzzle than a typical strategy game. While there are a few options/difficulty settings to choose from at the start of the game, and while some gameplay elements are randomized with each game, there is limited replayability. The tight turn limit means there isn't that much room for different strategies - you might play a few times to work out the right strategy and then move up to a higher difficulty level to try again, but every game will play mostly similarly.

That said, I had a lot of fun playing, and I like to think that I learned a few things. It looks, plays, and sounds nice, and I definitely feel like I got my money's worth out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023955681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1592052321}
review:
Nice game with lots of attention paid to detail and at the same time (I think) an accurate lesson in history

I will highly recommend it, for anyone liking games involved in managing ressources, people, happiness and military. 

Be aware, though, that you shouldn't expect to be able to play this game over and over again, as the stoty-line is, well, history. But get it for the superb gameplay, the nice artwork, the challenges and the lovely feel the game has. There seems to be a sequel coming up. I am definitely getting that as well

author: {'steamid': '76561198012449622', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1576, 'last_played': 1669834090}
review: After playing 26 hours, first try was the tutorial, next five tries did not complete, finally complete with a score of 11/33. You should take your time and read the cards carefully, you will learn about the ancient history. The game seems so very easy, but it is not. You must be very careful. This is a great game for parents to play with their children. But encourage them to take notes so that they can do better on the next try. I bought this game after Egypt: Old Kingdom so I already understood the game play. If you can do the series in order from beginning to end. Make for better continuity of the story. And yes, I waited till it was on sale, sorry I waited now, the game is a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007439582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1596399664}
review:
I can't complain too much since I got this game on sale for $3 but I may be a one and done player. Even at the easy level, Getting to the victory conditions is very difficult. You have to have the right amount of resources at the right time to get each victory condition built in time. That would require many play-throughs to get the sequence right and that's just the easy level. Not sure I find the game interesting enough to invest that much time in it. 
Alternate games: I still believe that Banished is the best city building game out there. For Egyptian city building, I prefer Children of the Nile. An old game but the best for my money in that genre.
developer_response: Thats a point of our game "That would require many play-throughs to get the sequence right and that's just the easy level." and if you don't like that type of gameplay we are realy sorry. Our game is a puzzle-like strategy and with real historical facts about almost unknown period of predynastic in ancient Egypt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042196566', 'num_games_owned': 1530, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 389, 'last_played': 1588244882}
review:
A resource management game set in, naturally enough, predynastic Egypt. The best part of the game is that this is more than window dressing -- enough research has been put into the setting to turn what scanty sources we have about the period into a coherent, believable story. I'm always in favour of exploring underexploited settings in video games, and in that setting the equivalent of a Wonder of the World is a stick in the ground, all the better.

A playthrough takes about three hours. This is not a freeform 4X, but rather you are faced with periodic challenges, some scripted some random, and need to streamline your growth curve to blast through them. As a result there's not much replay value -- play it once to learn the timings, a second time to beat them. I suppose if you want to maximise your score you could keep playing, but why?

author: {'steamid': '76561197984156162', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 234, 'last_played': 1616882427}
review:
Amazing. Really sucked me in, despite being a quite simplistic civilisation builder (kind of like Civ but not).

Quite difficult (will be on your first game, I played first one right through, and didn't manage to win (score 6/31 lol). Kind of a 'snowbally' game. Very early wins and advances/advantages will have a large impact on winning or not due to the strong snowball effect on your basic resources (there are a lot of buffs that are percentage based).

Educational and fun! Totally recommend, especially during the very generous sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561199043548226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 4647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1678339433}
review: Predynastic Egypt is one of those historical based games that has captured my attention.  If history, archaeology, and ancient civilizations are your thing, you will not be disappointed in this historical strategy turn-based single player game.  It literally feels like you are watching a culture and society grow before your eyes.  You begin on a regional map shrouded by clouds, with one small patch near the center revealed.  Starting with a small area and one worker, you have mini-goals set before you to achieve.  Your resources are food, labor,  and culture, to begin with, and as time goes on your workers grow and the map is revealed as you appoint those workers to explore, build, and even go to war, and two more resources are added; and your resources, village, culture, and power grow as you continue to unlock the tech tree and build tree.  Events  will occur to either help (e.g., gaining favor of the gods from time to time, opening trade with neutral or friendly tribes) or hurt (such as sand storms, drought, and attacks from the tribe worshiping Set) your efforts.   The game interface is understandable and easy, and the tutorial is not confusing at all.  The player has 200 turns to complete guiding the Predynastic Egyptians from a small wandering band of people to a culturally advanced united kingdom.  But be careful, if you get behind in achieving cultural advances or miss meeting the goals of certain events, such as building King Scorpion's Tomb before he dies (as I did) then your advancement gets derailed and things start going wrong.  So it is not a given that you will meet all your goals in uniting Upper and Lower Egypt in time if you screw up a few things along the way.  But hey, if you do, you can always start another game.  It is that fun.  At $9.99 this game is well worth it.

review:
Steam definitely needs a mediocre option. 
1) RNG
2) No replay value
3) No deep strategy and more like scripted gameplay
If you wanted, buy it on deep sale.

And for the beloved developer ;

developer_response:
Hello!
Did you manage to complete our game and get all the gold medals on the first attempt and gain 33 points? If so, then you are a true genius! And if not, then perhaps you always blamed that there is no replayability, and indeed we have a historical scenario describing the pre-dynastic ancient Egyptian history.

review:
Comparing to Marble Age, the game the from same company, it somehow gives me a feeling of Civilization. 

The minus side is that, it is still a cheap-game style, the goal is just to finish your trials at each phrases as perfect; and end the game as early; as you can. And its technology tree and the building just become a dumb tasks you have to finish.

The plus side is the history background it uses.

review: An interesting simulation of ancient egyptian civilization. Plays like a city building game, with worker allocation and resource management being the principal tasks. However, the playthrough is quite short and the game offers little replayability. Good to learn about History in an engaging way.
