author: {'steamid': '76561197998369151', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 11661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8952, 'last_played': 1523801793}
review: I have been looking for this kind of "ancient early civilization" game for a while now. It took a while to figure out what the ideal balance of worker placement should be, but making mistakes, starting over, and trying different approaches never became frustrating or inconvenient. If you enjoy any sort of recourse management/worker placement games, I think you will enjoy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198299653087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 370, 'last_played': 1603020807}
review:
Got the game for 5.5 â‚¬ on sale and in my opinion it totally worthed it. The game isn't long, i completed it in 4 hours (on easy difficulty). Perhaps I will run another game with historical or hard settings. I think it can be replayed but after some days or weeks.
The game is historically accurate and fun. You often need to do some micromanagment - especially at the begininng. After a time it gets a lot easier. It was nice to unify Egypt. This could be also done e.g. with Rome (with the same mechanics - would be nice).

author: {'steamid': '76561198013522036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 215, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1511139120}
review:
This is what a story-based strategy game should be. The gameplay follows the march of history with some allowance for variation but all the mechanics make a historical playthrough feel natural and accurate, and the quests give you direction as you pursue victory rather than, as in many games, being a mere distraction. 

It covers an interesting setting that is only more interesting because of its historicity, and is fun in its own right with educational merit as a happy addition.

As for replayability, which others have complained of, it is a (relatively short) narrative game, and so it does fall off under repeated playthroughs. That said, the game keeps score constantly, making it fun to play for purely mechanical reasons. There are constant "trials" - special events that tax your resources heavily - and winning the game takes proper prioritization and timing - and once you do, there's a score built from your acheivements and your decisions at game start. While the game may not be the sort I'd put a thousand hours into, it's definitely worth more than a single playthrough, and although it's short, it's also cheap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094282979', 'num_games_owned': 397, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1509739726}
review:
En la dicotomÃ­a â€œRecomendado/No Recomendadoâ€ este juego lo recomiendo, aunque estÃ¡ lejos de ser perfecto.

MuyLargoNoVoyaLeerte: Por el precio, es un juego que te darÃ¡ unas cuentas buenas horas de entretenimiento y te enseÃ±arÃ¡ de historia, pero tiene jugabilidad limitada. Darle una oportunidad si te gusta coleccionar juegos que solo juegas una vez y te encanta la historia como yo

El juego es de estrategia por turnos basado en el antiguo Egipto con el fin de conquistar todo el mapa y establecer la primera dinastÃ­a del â€œViejo Reinoâ€. Suena como la trama mÃ¡s trillada del mundo, pero lo original se encuentra en que aquÃ­ no hay ni piramides ni esfinges. Las pirÃ¡mides se muestran solo como pieza artÃ­stica y para seÃ±alar que ya hay un Estado egipcio como tal.

El objetivo no es construir las pirÃ¡mides y vencer a griegos, ni persas, ni romanos en forma completamente ahistÃ³rica, sino simplemente recorrer el camino que le tomÃ³ a una pequeÃ±a tribu nÃ³mada a formar una de las primeras â€œgrandes civilizacionesâ€.

Se te presentan 2 mapas, uno de tu â€œasentamientoâ€ y otro de Egipto. Administras 6 recursos: Trabajadores, grano (que representa toda la comida), producciÃ³n (que representa toda la manufactura, productos, minerÃ­a, etc.), ejÃ©rcito (solo nÃºmero de tropas), cultura (necesario para hacer descubrimientos) y Autoridad (que tanto poder ejerce el lÃ­der).

Para obtener recursos necesitarÃ¡s de trabajadores que arrastras a las â€œÃ¡reasâ€ (en tu mapa de asentamiento) o â€œciudadesâ€ (en tu mapa de Egipto). El costo de los trabajadores depende de cuantos tienes. AsÃ­ el primero te costarÃ¡ 32 unidades de grano, pero el 72 costarÃ¡ 2k unidades. TendrÃ¡s lÃ­mites de cuantos tener de acuerdo a tu nivel tecnolÃ³gico y edificios construidos, pero puedes pasarte del lÃ­mite a cambio de tener penalizaciones.

Lamentablemente el juego es bastante lineal. La producciÃ³n servirÃ¡ para mejorar campos y construir edificios pero no tienes libertad de elegir dÃ³nde construirlos, ni producir mÃ¡s de uno. Solo estÃ¡n lo que estÃ¡n presentes y ya. 

Para construir y obtener bonos de producciÃ³n investigaras tecnologÃ­as, pero de nuevo, esto es demasiado lineal, son 3 lÃ­neas y las tendrÃ¡s que investigar todas. EnseÃ±a bastante de historia, pero no te da libertad.

Para hacer la guerra usarÃ¡s un trabajador que prepararÃ¡ un ataque en un nÃºmero de turnos y la batalla es bÃ¡sicamente todos tus guerreros contra todos sus guerreros, sÃ³lo hay dos o tres tecnologÃ­as que afectan su efectividad.

El Ãºltimo recurso, la Autoridad, sirve principalmente para honrar a los Dioses y tener bonificaciones, sin embargo estÃ¡n bastante desequilibrados, de los 6 presentes algunos los usÃ© una vez, otros cada que podÃ­a, y otro solo lo usÃ© una vez pero me bastÃ³ para conquistar a todo Egipto.

Hay otras opciones que casi estÃ¡n de adorno. El comercio es prÃ¡cticamente inÃºtil a excepciÃ³n de, quizÃ¡s, hacerlo con Palestina, hay regiones que no vale la pena explorar en lo absoluto.

En resÃºmen, el juego te divierte sobre todo si te gusta la historia, y me parece original que se trate del Egipto previo a las pirÃ¡mides, a RamsÃ©s II y a Cleopatra, que es para los juegos de estrategia lo que la 2a Guerra Mundial es para los juegos de disparos. Sin embargo, aparte de poner/quitar bonificaciones u obstÃ¡culos como dificultades, tiene una casi nula rejugabilidad. No hay finales diferentes ni forma de alterar la historia, sigues una misma lÃ­nea de objetivos por alcanzar con la meta final de establecer Egipto antes del 3,000 a.c. 

Por el precio que dan y mÃ¡s que lo comprÃ© en oferta, me parece justo y entretenido. Aunque tal vez haya juegos similares gratuitos o semigratuitos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211387588', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1505751746}
review:
Really a mixed experience... rather enjoyable while it lasts, unfortunatelly that's not for long - a whole playthrough took me about the same time as it would took a single mission in some serious strategy game. But then again, this isn't really a strategy game, thing happen over and over again and there really is no reason to replay the whole thing again. Therefore, any price over a couple of euros is too much for it as you're gonna bag it after finising it once. Yes, there are achievements and you'll probably grind the game for those, but if it were for the game itself, you'd never open it again after finishing it once. 
That doesn't mean it's a bad game - the whole thing is really nicely packed and the game structure, graphics and everything is really nicely done. A lot of effort has been pumped into this thing, there's no doubt about it, and therefore I'll recommend it.. but there is still a lot of work to do if this is to become a real game and not some online or andriod time-killer...

good time waster, there seems to be only 1 win strat. i refuse to look it up on utube to get some more playtime out of the game.  think i paid $9...  it's probably more like a $4 game, really very little wiggle room if you want to win.  even on super easy noob mode.   

 again though i enjoyed the premise and the game; justwish there wasmore to it

author: {'steamid': '76561198100452320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1549842590}
review: Its incredible to see how far you guys have come. Starting with the free online game "pre civilizations: Stone age" and now being something as impressive fun to play and good as this. Its amazing. Keep up to good work guys!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039422068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1498855469}
review:
The game is fun on the first playthrough, but apart from getting all archievements has no replay value at all. The second game you start is an exact copy of the first one, you could literally write down what you did wrong on the first try to get max score the second time. After a few hours and winning the game instantly... thats about it... 

fun for once, not so much second time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072155841', 'num_games_owned': 1359, 'num_reviews': 586, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 461, 'last_played': 1503565590}
review:
Predynastic Egypt is a very interesting board-game style computer game, with the mechanism of resource management and worker placement as its core. You play the leader of an Egyptian tribe and guide your people to unify the whole Nile region. The game course is well designed to constantly give you the good feeling of development and achievement while pushing you forward with timed story events. And the higher difficulties are very challanging to most players.

The graphics are drawn in clean and warm ancient Egyptian style, the music fits its theme, and the control is simple yet well functional. There's also some history to learn from the game.

Although Predynastic Egypt is basically of the same genre as the previous product Marble Age from the studio, it shows a lot of improvements in various aspect. 

Highly recommened for strategy game funs, board game funs, and those interested in ancient Egypt history.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022408379', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1097, 'last_played': 1503085944}
review:
[h1]Nice educational, unpretentious strategic without the depth or replaiability of other similar games like Civilization.[/h1]

The historical aspect of the game is marvelously made, and it's its best selling point: if you like history and especially Egyptian history, you will enjoy the game and the various informations contained in it.

Regarding the game itself, it's a different story: Predynastic Egypt is a turn-based strategy game more similar to a board game like Risk/Risiko than a proper video game like Civilization: you merely move your workers on the map, deciding  which type of resources they have to work, and that's it. 
Sure, it lacks the depth of other strategic games, but it's still a very nice, unpretentious game.

It's not for everyone, though: Predynastic Egypt can be very difficult (the tutorial is extremely short and doesn't fully prepare for what lies ahead) and unforgiving; on the higher difficulties, that means that you'll have to follow some precise strategies to ensure victory, severely limiting your game freedoom.
And this is perhaps the game's biggest flaw: freedom and repleability. The game (logically) takes place always on the same map, with the same starting position, the same trials, the same victory conditions and the same terrain yeld [b]for every single campaign[/b] (also every game will always see the same number of tribes, albeit randomized in position, goods and attitude, and the randomized events will always happen on the same turns), meaning that you'll need to adopt always the same strategies to win. leaving very, [very] limited space for creativity and improvisation.

Despite this burdensome flaw, I still reccomend this game for history enthusiasts or for everyone who wants to spend some hours with a relaxing and educational game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064237075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1502895385}
review:
I want to like the game but, in all honesty, it just doesn't feel like a game.

When I bought the game I had already seen a few reviews saying stuff like "you can't deviate from the set strategy if you want to win". I figured people were exaggerating and that the game was simply 'difficult' to clear. (Which is actually a good thing.) 
But with nearly 15 hours on record, a third on my own and two thirds attempting to follow the best guide out there, a ridiculous amount of save-scamming and far too much frustration,  I now can say you truly cannot deviate from the set strategy if you want to beat this game. 

And guess what...
That's not a game. That's click-bait.

I don't buy a game so that I can print out and follow a paper which tells me when to click which button. I buy a game so that I may challenge myself and reach the end goal through various different strategies. Let me try economy. Let me try military. Let me try culture. Give me options. Give me value. Give me a [b]game[/b].

author: {'steamid': '76561198099302110', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1237, 'last_played': 1686178274}
review: Surprising little turn-based strategy game with the rise of Ancient Egypt with must research done and painstaking accurate art. Beyond this, the gameplay is simple to pick up yet difficult to master, allowing beginners and veterans of the turn-based genre to enjoy. As a personal lover of Ancient Egypt, I quite enjoyed this and can't wait for the Old Kingdom sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971580755', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 961, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1501639899}
review: Definitely worth playing if you love a single player board game / puzzle. The game isn't too hard to beat, but getting a high score is a real challenge that is fun to repeat. Some minor randomization keeps things fresh but never interferes with the fun too much. I disagree with the reviews which say it is too hard to defeat the rival clan, or that it changes to a different game halfway through, it is just an additional layer of complexity for once you have the hang of things. Just because you lose a challenge does not end the game, it is actually fairly difficult to fail so hard the game ends. It mostly impacts your points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031302987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1501343723}
review:
The game is fun and teaches you a bit of history in the process (though some of it not entirely accurate), but be aware that you're paying for about 2.5 hours worth of game, at least on the easiest setting.

There is very little randomness, and even that's mostly in the tribe names. For example a tribe may be called the Bull tribe in one game, but the Flax Flower tribe in another, but it will be in the same place, trade the same things, and have the same military strength. So essentially if you replay it, you'll see the exact same game again with different icons on the map. After you've finished it once, well, the only reason to replay is to see if you can do it on a higher difficulty.

I mean, lliterally. You may or may not be able to see that I've played it for 5.8 hours, but that was playing it twice, plus a couple of false starts. I had to play it again to see if anything was different. It wasn't.

Still, for this kind of money, I guess it's not too bad. Short and sweet beats long and dilluted.

review:
Something between a boardgame and the Civilization. 
Very atmospheric. 
Somewhat educational. 
Good art and music.

And you can worship Horus. ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198027640011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 790, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1595521305}
review: Pretty cool game, the artstyle is beautiful, and the feel of the game is really nice. It is surprisingly replayable, because each game you try to get a better score, although it lasts around two hours from start to finish (making easy to finish in one session), so after a while you might get tired of it. If you like civ's building aspect and are all about optimization you'll probably enjoy the game. The historical events side is pretty nice and I think the pace and sense of progression you get is well done.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025529029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 794, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1500249830}
review:
A relatively simplistic game, it's fun the first time around but doesn't have a lot of re-playability -- unless you want to break out the spreadsheets in order to try to maximize your score.  

There is little to no flexibility or actual choices involved in this game -- in order to win the game, you must complete the same basic steps, re civilization/knowledge development or in city building, every time you play.  There is also only one 'winning' outcome, which makes the game less enjoyable on replay.

However, the first play-through is enjoyable!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007901952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1500125902}
review:
If you're here for the killer of the Civilizations franchise, I'm sorry. You came to the wrong place.

If you're here for a game with appropriate and beautiful art, accurate and deep tech, with plenty of factual information....
You won't regret your purchase. I certainly have not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002567771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 1579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 731, 'last_played': 1651586306}
review:
Predynastic Egypt is a resource management and optimization game in which you overcome trials and ordeals and establish Egypt as unified kingdom.
From humble beginnings with simple decisions to make to managing a large amount of workers while planning several turns ahead, Predynastic Egypt offers a pleasant if a bit simple of an experience. There aren't a lot of different mechanics involved, but they do not need to be. With a simple foundation and easily controlled, intuitive basic gameplay you'll be able to manage your tribe and deal with what Egypt has to offer. Multiple difficulty options allow you to customize the game to your liking while everything is explained in enough detail that you will not have to worry about not knowing what is going on, though it still doesn't give you more information than you really need.

One concern is replayability. As it is the same map every time, with the same ordeals every time at the same turns it becomes predictable and later playthroughs will feel repetitive. At the highest difficulties, it's all about solving everything perfectly, with perfect timing on everything and good luck on the random events. If you enjoy achievement hunting, you will get plenty of replayability out of it, but otherwise there isn't much reason to play it a second time.

As for the trials and ordeals, they are challenging when you first go through them, but fair. With a bit of planning and forward thinking you can win the game on your first try. Playthroughs after the first will make it a lot easier and unless you actively avoid doing them it is difficult to really fail at any of them.

A relaxed atmosphere and simple base mechanic means this is mostly a casual game, pleasant to play and worth the time to get it, Predynastic Egypt does what it tells you it does, does it very well, and overall delivers a good experience at a good price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005391568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 6459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1696087301}
review:
Ce petit jeu est vraiment sympa et extrÃªmement addictif, contrairement Ã  ce qui a Ã©tÃ© dit dans d'autres commentaires sa rejouabilitÃ© est assez efficace car c'est la troisiÃ¨me fois que je le recommence (en facile) et je n'ai toujours pas gagnÃ© (je m'y remets donc demain).

[b]Le jeu[/b] consiste Ã  faire prospÃ©rer votre village Ã©gyptien durant la pÃ©riode prÃ© dynastique pour peu Ã  peu crÃ©er une grande mÃ©tropole, unir l'Egypte, dÃ©couvrir un panthÃ©on unique et vaincre vos ennemis.

Vous passerez tout votre temps Ã  crÃ©er puis positionner des travailleurs sur certaines cases que vous amÃ©nagerez, et dont les carractÃ©ristiques Ã©volueront au fil du temps, l'astuce Ã©tant de ne jamais manquer des diverses ressources du jeu sous peine d'Ã¨tre ralenti et de ne pouvoir rÃ©unir les conditions de victoire du jeu.

Votre ressource principale sera la nourriture, indispensable pour crÃ©er des travailleurs qui cultiveront vos terres. Puis ce sera la production, sous forme de marteaux, et ensuite la culture, votre armÃ©e et l'autoritÃ©, pour les technologies et la religion/ordre public.
Vous positionnerez donc vos travailleurs sur des cases champs, des mines, construirez maisons et temples et y positionnerez Ã©galement vos travailleurs, tout cela vous rapportant des ressources chaque tour de jeu.
Vous consommerez une partie de ces rerssources pour faire tourner votre colonie qui deviendra ville puis mÃ©gapole, le but Ã©tant d'Ãªtre dans le positif (chiffre jaune et non rouge) dans chacune des catÃ©gories que je viens de citer (nourriture, production...).

Pour exemple, pour crÃ©er le panthÃ©on unique (une des conditions de victoire), il faut avant la fin du jeu avoir progressÃ© tout au bout de l'arborescence des dÃ©couvertes culturelles, scientifiques et militaires, puis au dernier palier dÃ©penser 40K de culture pour dÃ©bloquer le panthÃ©on unique, or jusqu'Ã  ce jour je n'ai jamais rÃ©ussi, il me manque la moitiÃ© lorsque le gong annonÃ§ant la fin du jeu retentit.
Il va donc falloir que je me creuse les mÃ©ninges et place plus judicieusement mes travailleurs pour ne manquer de rien pendant le jeu et atteindre ce chiffre en culture.

Le jeu se joue en tour par tour, mais il n'y a que vous qui jouez, la fin d'un tour ne faisant qu'avancer le temps et vos actions (construire un bÃ¢timent, amasser assez de blÃ© pour crÃ©er un nouveau travailleur...).
Par contre au fil du temps vous subirez divers Ã©vÃ©nements alÃ©atoirs, positifs ou nÃ©gatifs comme des changements climatiques (pluie ou sÃ¨cheresse), des attaques ennemies, des rebellions si vous n'y prÃ©tez pas attention, et vous devrez parfois vous aussi attaquer certaines tribus qui vous sont hostiles.

Une partie dure environs 2 Ã  3 heures, ce qui se fait souvent d'un trait tant le jeu est prenant.

Je le conseille donc vivement Ã  tous les amateurs de stratÃ©gie/gestion, et pour son modique prix (et sa configuration minimale qui permettra de le faire tourner sur le PC de papy), pourquoi se priver?

author: {'steamid': '76561198068603673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1560695554}
review: Fun at first, but the game is over after 3 hours, even though everything was going so well. Building, exploring and expanding is fun. Felt like a more user friendly crusader kings. Researching new stuff and build your empire is really cool, and i though i was in for a long exiting game. But 3 hours in, the game is nearing the end and everything is you build is comprimised to race to the finish for the best possible score. And thats it. At its core its a fun game. But it's just to short. 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046981840', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1499022366}
review: Amazing game. Saw it in a Quill18 let's play and had to buy it. Finished one game and will try one more for a perfect score. The price is fair since the replayability of this game is fairly low. If you like strategy and history, this is something for you. expect to be entertained for 4 to 12 hours with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993755170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1503817852}
review:
Really interesting civ-like. As everything you build goes in its historical place, and it follows the historical record of events, you feel a bit led. I enjoyed the planning and searching fore that extra bit of efficiency at every point.

I think it will lack replyability, but I enjoyed playing through it a few times until I got a win. Well worth the price.

If they released a new game about a different period/place (Mayan kingdoms pls) - I would probably buy it immediately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009861178', 'num_games_owned': 322, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 566, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1499024937}
review:
[h1]Intro[/h1]
Predynastic Egypt vom russischen Indie Entwickler Clarus Victoria ist ein kleines aber feines Strategie-/Aufbauspiel. Der Spieler erlebt die die Geschichte Ã„gyptens lange vor der Zeit der Pyramiden, aus der Zeit als sie noch ein Nomadenvolk waren und sesshaft wurden.

[h1]Inhalt[/h1]
Das Spiel spielt sich ein wenig wie ein Brett- bzw. Kartenspiel. Man verbringt die Zeit damit abzuwÃ¤gen wie man seine BÃ¼rger in die vorgesehene Slots einsetzt, Ã¤hnlich wie die BÃ¼rger im Stadtmenu aus Civilization, nur dass es hier komplexer ist. Auf die Art kann man erkunden, Nahrung beschaffen, Produktion betreiben, forschen, kÃ¤mpfen, handeln, etc.
Man forscht neue Technologien, kann neue Einrichtungen bauen, die Einwohnerzahl erhÃ¶hen (die dann natÃ¼rlich auch mehr Nahrung benÃ¶tigen). Das ganze verlÃ¤uft in Runden ab. Der Spieler erfÃ¤hrt viel Ã¼ber die Geschichte.

[h1]Urteil[/h1]
Warum ich dieses Spiel mag:
[list]
    [*]der gemalte Grafikstil im Ã¤gyptischen Setting (kein Mobile-Comic-Look)
    [*]sehr einfacher Einstieg, man kommt sofort zurecht
    [*]das Spiel ist an sich simpel, der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist aber angemessen und fordernd und spannend
    [*]interessante HintergrÃ¼nde Ã¼ber die Geschichte
    [*]schÃ¶ne Ã¤gyptischer Thememusik
    [*]die typische Aufbau-Optimierungsspirale greift hier gut: wachsen, erobern, forschen, optimieren
    [*]SchÃ¶ne UI die stark an Civ5 erinnert.
[/list]

Was ich noch gerne gehabt hÃ¤tte:
Es hat leider keinen hohen Wiederspielwert. Man wÃ¼rde es gerne sofort wieder spielen, es hÃ¤lt sich aber halt an die Geschichte, die halt leider nicht viel Abwechslung bietet (trotz verschiedener Schwierigkeitsgrade und einiger Zufallsereignisse).
Mit Zufallsmaps (Geschichte hin oder her) hÃ¤tte das Spiel VIEL Potential, aber auch so ist es ein kleines schÃ¶nes Indie-Spiel dass fÃ¼r seine wenige Stunden begeistern kann. Ich wÃ¼rde es wieder kaufen. Ich hatte danach total Bock Pharaoh zu zocken, gerade weil es eigentlich direkt danach anknÃ¼pft... ^^

author: {'steamid': '76561197987312565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 321, 'last_played': 1498868747}
review:
Very good for one or two playthroughs, mostly for the setting/'story' value; it provides great insight into how prehistoric and early-historic cultures worked, and is generally very educational about a less-explored time in history.

For repeat playthroughs however, the game is far too scripted, the map is not randomized in any way, and the balance generally seems way off in the later, with events and tech providing far too many bonuses compared to just regular tiles, which makes the whole process of moving pops around somewhat pointless.

Definitely recommended for the price, but think of it more like a one-off experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009798025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1499876722}
review:
This is a great little game! It's like a cross between Sid Meiers Civilisations, and the old city-builder games of Sierra, specifically Pharaoh from 1999. If you enjoy either of these you will likely enjoy this one!
[b] TL:DR at the end. [/b]

The game is not large or long, as depending on your playspeed and how many playthroughs you do, it will take you between 10-25 hours to complete. And yes this game has some replayabiliy as you are not likely to 'beat' the game on your first try! [spoiler] (The game will still let you keep on playing even if don't fullfill all the objectives by the 220th turn though) [/spoiler]

You play through the foundation of ancient Egypt. As you follow the path to unification the story explains where, how & why, through text, the history of the period. There are no actual building of the Pyramids, as those where built much later during the dynastic-periods.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The challenge of the game is to figure how to beat it, and this may take multiple playthroughs to do. If this is enjoyable or not is completely up to you, but as a Civilisation & City-builder veteran I really liked it. Also unlike those games, 'where you at one point in the middle of the game feel like you have already won and you just keep pressing that end turn button untill you see the victory screen', this game is actually challenging all the way through untill the end!Â It's designed with a specific playstyle in mind, not leaving much freedom to do things in multiple different ways. Whereas Civ V has 5 different ways of winning the game, Predynastic Egypt only have 1, and there is only one route to it.

You start off with a single 'worker' or 'citizen' to gather food and scout the fog-of-war with, untill you can gather enough food for your second. You assign these to workers to different tiles for different yields Civ-style. (+food, +production or +culture for ex). The game asks you to grow to three population to complete the first chapter. Later you unlock the ability to build buildings, spend culture for Discoveries and authority for Worship. Discoveries is the research off new stuff, and Worship gives you powerful but temporary buffs (like +1 food per farm for 3 turns). 

The goal of the game is to grow your city, encounter local tribes and rival tribal-cities on the map of Egypt, and eventually unifying them into a single kingdom! These tribes you can also raid or trade with; before conquering or integrateing, to add to your proto-kingdom. 

Different stages of the game has you complete different obectives to advance to the next stage, often accompanied with timed missions which you can succeed with a Bronze, Silver or Gold rating. These missions can be to build a temple-building for your god, or to defend against an invasion. The ever increasing challenge of these contributes to a much more difficult and interresting end-game. You are told in advance what type or resources you will need for the mission ahead in general, but no details.

Random events also happens that can help you a lot or harm you a lot. These will be frustrating for some players, those who despises randomness. [i](Think about what some people thought about Darkest Dungeon in their steamreviews. Not nearly as much randomness here though).[/i] The occurrence of these can be turned down in the difficult menu, but not removed completely.

[h1] Graphics & Sound [/h1]
The Artsyle of the worker-cards, eventpictures, enviroments, backgrounds (On both Local-map and Egypt-map), are all great! The Iconc art of ancient Egypt is imitated well with lots of details. 

Soundesign is also good as background music sets the tone and the ambient sound changes as you scroll over the map hovering over water, fields and cities. 

Voice action is completely absent, but would be nice to have since there is a lot of description text...

The U.I design is as almost a copy of Civ V, with some elements like for ex. the dual-map from Pharaoh. This is a good thing!

[h1] Bugs [/h1]
I only encountered one bug. I was using a worship to give my farms +1 food for 3 turns, but an event popped up changing the worship to a % base insted. This caused all my farms to bugout, giving 0 food and becoming unworkable. This caused me to have -150 food and my population to die in starvation! Nothing I could to change it.

I managed to reload an earlier auto-save, and by doing things differently & in an inferior way I could avoid the bug. I reported to the bug to Clarus Victoria and will update this review if they fix the bug.

[h1] Finish [/h1] [b] TL:DR [/b]
Lets try and keep this short. Do I like it? Yes. Do I recommend it to you? Depends on if you like Min-Maxing and replaying untill you 'figure out' the best way of doing things. Also you must have a stomach to handle RNG-events that can fuck you up if timed badly. 

Do you feel the need to have multiple separate, and very different, paths towards reaching the same goal? Personally I don't think this game needs that. You are here to solve a challenge by Min-Maxing and replaying, even if the path is somewhat linear. It's not necessary for every game to have the ability to be played in more then one way, and that is perfectly fine by me.

The management of Civilisations (albeit without the multiple ways of 'winning the game') and the atmosphere & nostalgia of Pharaoh 1999 + the others in that series is what made this fun for me!

You also got to look at the value-for-money. For this low price you get enjoyment for about 10-25 hours, tyring to find the solution for the pussle at hand. Is this good value for you? This cost me 6.99 on a discount, but I would still recommend it at full-price!

author: {'steamid': '76561197990453869', 'num_games_owned': 924, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 771, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 642, 'last_played': 1499111205}
review:
1* This game is a blast, pure and simple. If you like strategy, this is for you.
2* As the (immensely lucky) partner of an Egyptologist, I commend its historical accuracy: this game is the standing proof that you don't have to go Assassin's Creed to make history interesting. Kudos!

author: {'steamid': '76561197993166835', 'num_games_owned': 523, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1498933970}
review: This game has great first half and boring second half. As the focus of the game shifts from managing a settlement of a handful of workers to managing several cities, the game becomes less and less fun. The tech tree turns into a set of bland modifier bonuses, and the available choices boil down to mashing "Reform: make life in Egypt easier, +5% to everything" button in order to meet an arbitrary and ridiculously high resource target as a final challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052472583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 243, 'last_played': 1538207262}
review: A fun small turnbased strategy game. It needs a competative element, or replayability, by adding/modding the possibility of playing multiple or different tribes and their gods, to explore other elements of Kemet. A city in each of the areas could add some interesting game play, instead of farming them like a regular tile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021763496', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1500822977}
review:
This is a fun game. But three things break it: 
1. The extremely tight turn limit to achieve victory even on the easiest difficulty
2. The lack of gameplay flexibility to explore alternative strategies because of 1, leading to scripted gameplay where you must follow a fixed path to victory or lose
3. Random negative events that happen anytime, aggravating 1. and 2.

I don't think this game was properly tested on all difficulties. It recommends new players try the easiest difficulty, yet lacks the flexibility for the slightest margin of error even at that difficulty. Even those who manage to complete it on the hardest difficulty can only explain a single way to beat the game. They are unable to explain how to exploit different strategies to achieve victory even though the game gives the impression of such "flexibility" through a diverse tech tree and wide selection of building improvements. This is because the very short turn limit to achieve victory, coupled with arbitrary (by this I mean untested on all difficulties) victory requirements, negates such a notion. 

Many available techs and building improvements could not be researched/built in my attempt to meet the victory requirements because of the short turn limit. For example, the tech point requirement for every subsequent tech scales up as part of the progression mechanic and the second last tech just before the victory tech costs 5000 tech points. This is fine in itself except that the victory tech itself costs 45000 tech points, which is a sudden ninefold jump in tech requirements and appears extremely arbitrary just to make the game "challenging" without proper testing on all difficulties as mentioned. Note that I proritized spending tech points only on techs that allow me to reach this victory tech in as short a path as possible to avoid wasting points on unnecessary techs. I also put a high priority to allocating workers on tiles that give huge tech point bonuses each turn and frequently played options that gave tech bonuses. Yet the game ended when I only had around half the required tech points needed for victory.

In other words, you have to play by the script or lose due to the lack of margin for error even on the easiest difficulty as explained earlier. Do not get me wrong. I like challenging games. But if the challenges do not scale according to the difficulty and are not tested for this, and scripted gameplay is forced on the player to win, there's really nothing to look forward to in the game in terms of replayability. This game is just worth a few hours of entertainment and no more than that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066213862', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1476536269}

author: {'steamid': '76561198047134587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 226, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1497088775}
review:
Just don't waste your time. It is not a strategy, just a puzzle. And one that requires you to simply know all scripted events and trails and prepare for them. There are few things that are random, including combat. In other games that increases re-playability but here it might make following optimal path no longer possible. If you don't get "gold" from trial you don't get associated bonuses and it will be hard to complete next goals.

Other miscellaneous stuff:
- horizontal scroll in technology & save windows is annoying
- fields don't have fixed production, some buildings not only increase but replace production and it is hard to tell exactly what (and where) will happen. Even worse, some of those changes are triggered by scouting/turn progress (at least it looks that way)
- it is hard to estimate "+x%" bonuses impact, it seems like result is rounded up instead of nearest integer.

TL;DR: it is a mix of typical worker placement boardgame (like Agricola) with original Homeworld campaign style( do mission perfectly or you will hit impassable wall in future).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035467587', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1518000652}
review:
A fun little game, that will scratch the itch for people who enjoyed games like Pharaoh. It's not nearly as detailed or in-depth as the old City Builders, but it's not pretending to be (or even trying). What it does, it does well.

Pros: Pleasing art style and visuals; gentle learning process; good attention to historical detail (where possible); fun sense of progression and growth from tiny group of hunters to political powerhouse.

Cons: cluttered UI, that isn't always easy to follow; objectives/missions sometimes not explained very clearly. Minor issues, really. 

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198060718434', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 516, 'last_played': 1494274305}
review:
Fun little game that can be somewhat challenging on the hardest difficulty options. It's not enough to be considered a real strategy game, more like a city management. I'm truly sad at the lack of variety of ways you can tackle the gamethrough, basically focus on construction and culture and you'll win regardless. And the combat system is lackluster and boring at best.

Nevertheless, it is entertaining enough to catch your eye for a few hours, at is intended. I recommend this game but only on a big sale.

7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983563283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1488708539}
review:
[h1]Overall good game with some flaws - recommended if its on discount or if you are into history.[/h1]

[b]Length:[/b]
I will start of with my main critique.
This game has just one campaign and it always plays on the same map.
You always start in the same position and the first events always play out the same. There is a turnlimit before you lose so every game will end at some point if you do not manage to win earlier.
One playthrough will take maybe around 2h.

[b]Strategic Aspect:[/b]
While it might not sound very promising up to this point you can easily play it a couple of times without getting bored. There are several strategic ways to progress further into the campaign and all of them have their strenghths and weaknesses and will guide you in a bit different manner through the game. Do you want to focus more on military and technology or do you want strong economics and be in favor with the gods? Its your choice.
Depending on your playstyle and difficulty setting the game can be hard.
I played it 3 times to the end and failed 2 times (2nd time I would have won just a single turn after the game ended in a defeat). All 3 plays were pretty different after the starting phase.
 
[b]Sound, Graphics & Atmosphere:[/b]
The graphics, while simple, are nicely done and fitting and so are sound and  music.
It has pleasing flair that will grab you and put in the right mood for such a game. 
I would see this as a strongpoint of the game.

[b]Historic Aspect:[/b]
If you have the desire you can learn a bit from this game. I tries to show you the development of ancient Egypt and can teach you a couple of cool things if you are willing to listen.
A nice bonus for me.


[b]Summary:[/b]
This is no Blockbuster or AAA title and it tries not to be one. If you are into history, ancient cultures or simply if its on sale and you want to try a bit of a different strategy/building/management game, this can be the right game for you.
I picked it up in a sale and while I have only played like 6 hours I would see my money well invested.
I am pretty sure that I will play it at some point later on if I am in the right mood again.
That for less money than eating out a in a fast food restaurant? Yeah sure - I will take it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006670466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1489344600}
review:
I have seen other reviews comparing Predynastic Egypt to Civilisation. Well apart from being turn-bases, the fact that you have to manage your workers and have to develop new tech, the game does its own thing. It also has elements of the old city builder series like Pharaoh. But its more about recreating Hierakonpolis as it was. That means you don't get that much agency over where the farms, temples etc gets to be placed. It's not a sandbox game like that of Pharaoh. You are more guided by historical accuracy when it comes to that. But since I am a big history nerd too I quite like it. 

the core of the game is going through the trials of developing Hierakonpolis, first as a small tribal village and then gradually scouting out and developing the area around the city. Hereby making it a hub for farming, worship, craftsmen and the training of your army. Later a map for whole Egypt opens op. 

On this map you explore even more and deal with other tribes; trading with them, persuading them to join you or crushing them with your army. 

Most of you time are spent on managing your workers. moving them from farming to for instance worship when you need the favour of a god to overcoming a trial/mission more easily. The main goal is to unite the tribes of Egypt, creating a single pantheon and the society that the dynasties of the Pharaohs would rule.  

the good things: 
- interesting historical setting that is incredibly well researched.
- the small animations of your workers, that look like old paintings from Egyptian tombs coming to life is incredibly well made. It makes the game look a lot more lively. It's almost a metaphor for the core of the game: bringing Egypt's history to life
- Challenges that require you to think and balance food, culture, production and getting new tech. As well as taking over other tribes or focusing on internal deveopment of your capital city. 

the features that could use improvement: 
- Combat. Currently, it's mostly a numbers game. The ones with the strongest army in terms of numbers wins. There are small battle events that can happen like "the enemy attacks from an ambush!" which is just written in text, nothing the player can do influence about it. I understand that combat is not the main feature of the game but it would be cool with more agency to the player in combat. Being able to choose tactics (like feint, hit-and-run, all-out attack etc) would be an improvement. 
- Worker management; being able to at the click of a button to prioritise workers to different resources.  it can be a bit much having to manage every work individually.


Overall a great little indie game with great potential for a sequel - and it's cheap in price too!

review:
If I could give this game a sideways thumb I would.
It i a good game for a few playthroughs but lacks replayability.
I got about 8hrs ( maybe 2hrs per game it is short ) fun for 10.99 $Cdn not quite enough to justifie a thumbs up from me.
If your one of those people who will play something over and over trying to get a better score and more achievments then you will have a better experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086858836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1543017367}
review: While this looks better than the previous titles, I definitely preferred the sliders of the previous game. This one with the random combat and random events relies on luck a lot more heavily to win. I have played three games of this, each one lasting about 2 hours and I am bored. The previous title had games that lasted 3-4 hours and after about 10 games I'm still not bored. I think my money was better spent on Pre Civilization: Marble Age.
developer_response:
Hi! Thanks for your opinion, even if itâ€™s a bad one. We hope it will help us to make better games in future. Sorry for your experience, but all information you found in the game and game story is based on real history of Predynastic Egypt approved by professional scientists and Egyptologists. The map you are complaining about â€“ is a real map of ancient Hierakonpolis with reconstructed buildings. You can check the excavation site yourself here http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org Same with the choices â€“ since we are not sandbox â€“ we canâ€™t change the history. We are trying to improve replayability by different Prologue settings, adding interesting achievements and working on Steam Workshop where we want to allow the players make the own history.

If you have any questions or ideas please share it with us here http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/350544272221845683/ 

Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198278741140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1589, 'last_played': 1488554986}
review: If you like Marble Age and other such resource allocation turn based strategy games, this is a solid entry in the genre. From the developers of Marble Age, they turn this time to Ancient Egypt and the historical events of the early dynasties. The gameplay is very simple, but difficult to master. There's a small learning curve at first as you stumble across some common strategic mistakes. However, it takes time and effort to really be able to play the game on hard mode. The resource distribution is random, so each playthrough presents some different challenges and you cannot rely on a single strategy to skate through the game. If you dig this type of strategy game, it's very well made and offers many hours of gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136712465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 13040, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4259, 'last_played': 1496981996}
review:
This is a very good turn-based strategy game. One game lasts around 200 turns, divided into 3 periods: the building of the first city, the conquest of the Nile, and a period of great prosperity. During each period, there is a number of trials to complete, and then a series of random events. The main line of the game and the trials follow the historical development of Ancient Egypt, from the times of nomadic hunter-gatherers up to the unification of all lands along the Nile and the first great kings. The developers found a balance between historical accuracy and enjoyment; there is a wealth of information to learn about these ancient times, presented as short paragraphs after events or discoveries. I learnt quite a few things!

The game uses 2 maps, one for the first city, and one for the region around the Nile. These maps must be explored to unlock land and resources, discover and interact with different tribes. There are 4 types of resources, used to grow the population, build city improvements, discover knowledge, receive favors from gods or help with the completion of trials. Interaction with tribes include raids and conquests, trade, and the sending of gifts to curry favor. Better relations lead to bonuses to trade, or the ability to peacefully merge with the tribe. Random events happen at fixed turns during the game, simulating either actions from tribes, natural phenomena, or internal affairs.

To achieve a good score at the end of the game, it is necessary to plan carefully what and when to research or build, how much to grow or explore. This includes some micro-management like where to place units to produce the desired level of each resource. How much of a given resource is available at a given spot varies during the development of the game,  either as a consequence of random events, or as a historical consequence (like the change of climate over the period covered by the game). Discoveries and buildings also impact available resources.

Each period plays as a tactical race to achieve a number of goals, marked by the trials; the player is kept under pressure, as achieving "gold level" on every trial is not easy. Not only planning is crucial, but the careful execution of a strategy is necessary. Each turn, each action, each unit counts. Sadly, the pressure can be so high that a single unfavorable random event may sometimes cause the expected mid-to-long term goal to be irreparably missed, even when understanding the fine points of the game mechanics. Getting one of the best scores involves some level of luck (aka save scumming), which is a drawback in a strategy game.

The graphics are charming, beautiful, and their style serves the gameplay and historical background well. The music is relaxing and unobtrusive, and the sound effects well done. The UI is intuitive, entirely made of clicks, drags and drops.

I highly recommend this game to any who enjoy a strategic challenge and are looking for a different (refreshing) setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001082529', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1497452994}
review:
Remember those educational games you played as a kid on your first PC where you had fun just learning and messing around? It's like that but with crocodiles and Ra.

If you love Egyptian history, espesically time period before what you would normally hear/read about, this game is for you. It doesn't hurt if you like to manage production too since it's mostly about that. It's short but it's highly unlikely that you're going to win the first time around so you want to replay it over and over to keep trying. There are hard fail states in the game that I don't like but if you can prepare for them adequately, you can get past them. I don't like some minor things about this game but it's so rare to have a game set in this time period, in fact I think it might be the only one, that it's worth the cheap price to try it out and learn something.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028635918', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1896, 'last_played': 1485362288}
review:
Got this game during Steam sale. It's a turn based puzzle game with story background covering ancient Egypt. It may look very simplistic but once you start playing it, you find lots of in-game features.

Your goal is to build up your initial colony and explore nearby areas. This is done by acquiring citizens and placing them to various free slots across the map, each one giving you different resources. Soon, during the gameplay, different buildings and cultures are presented to you, both of which giving you various perks that help improve your colony. Once your initial area gets fully explored, your next goal is to discover whole Egypt. During this phase of the game, military and trading becomes more of a priority, since more tribes start appearing to you. Establishing strong alliances, conquering areas and dealing with many random events (some are good, some are bad) are key factors for achieving unification of Egypt - game victory.

While the game is short and may get repetitive fairly quickly, it still offers an interesting story of colonization of Egypt and a variety of different game mechanics. In my opinion, the achievements are well made and give the game the much needed replayability value. I'm currently 40 hours into the game and still struggling to get them all. This means, you need to pick all kinds of strategies to perfect this game 100%.

Overall, it's a solid little game for the price. The learning curve may be difficult at first, but it's still fun once you get a grasp of it. If you like these kind of games, you should check out Marble Age, which was published by the same company.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118646272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1542231956}
review:
I was an archaeologist and I play this game with my girlfriend, who is an Egyptologist (and she studies the predynastic too!!!). We strongly suggest this game if you know nothing about predynastic Egypt because of its accuracy. It is a very funny way of learning something about a not so well known period. 
Otherwise, it's even funnier if you already have some knowledge about it... 
The game mechanics are very easy to learn but it's not simple to master the game to a full victory, even if you know the historical background... 

Strongly reccomended!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994450531', 'num_games_owned': 149, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1483614853}
review:
Short but interesting game.
Definitely the potential for something bigger/better with the same game model; if the game had no turn/time limits but instead functioned by goals under a "neverending" mode it would benefit from it. The larger world map with access to other factions and even the possibility to play other cultures could make a very interesting game and definitly something worth paying more for, a grand strategy board game on the style of Diplomacy/Risk.
As it stands, it's a cute little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198215792644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 193, 'last_played': 1483405292}
review: I got this game on sale during the winter sale. For the price I paid, I think it was worth it but you beat the game in about two hours and then just go back to try and get achievements.
developer_response:
Hi! Thanks for the review, it will help us to make future games even better.

You spent about hours in the game? Sorry fro you experience, but this is a true story of Pre-Dynastic Egypt, we are unable to step away from it at the expense of historicity and make civ-clone or something like that. What we can offer here is the real city reconstruction http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org â€“ there are excavations there, on the same map that you see in the game. It is one of the strongest features in the game, because all information you found in the game endorsed by the scientists and Egyptologists.

And you can share with us your ideas how to make the game interesting http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/350544272221845683/

author: {'steamid': '76561198056080377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1901, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1528704912}
review: This is an outstanding game.  It is historically-informed, it is challenging, and it is very fun.  The UI and gameplay, as well as the soundtrack, are excellent, and so is the tutorial system.  It's a great concept going back to the formation of a major civilization like Egypt and playing through that.  I'd love to see more games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039377370', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 291, 'last_played': 1595443596}
review:
This game remids me more of a worker placement tabletop game (like Argicola or Le Havre) than a civ building game, though it also has some elements of civ building. You esentially place your workers in different tiles to get resources, wich you use to produce more workers, upgrade your tiles, etc. You also have to gather resources to overcome different set events. 

 The map is not random (some minor things change, though) so the replayability lies in  trying to optimice your strategy in order to beat the game, wich is not easy at all. In that sense, it feels a bit like a puzzle game.

 Finally, I'd like to mention that the history is really good. It's a period rarely explored in games and the portrayal of it is faithful to reality. That said, I wish there were some text detailing the actual historical details of each event, so you can learn from the game.

 Persoanlly, I liked the game, but be aware that it's not a civ game at all. It's a worker placement game with a civ building theme.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041239133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482968479}
review:
It's an okay game, with very nice art. But after one playthrough you're pretty much done with it.

The different scenarios/starting conditions are almost identical to each other, which really frustrated me.
developer_response:
Greetings! Thanks for your opinion, even if itâ€™s a bad one. We hope it will help us to make better games in future.

Sorry for your experience, but our game is not like usual sandbox games or games you playing in historical setting (like Civ series or Total War or name any game like this). All information you found in the game and game story is based on real history of Predynastic Egypt approved by professional scientists and Egyptologists. The map you are complaining about â€“ is a real map of ancient Hierakonpolis with reconstructed buildings. You can check the excavation site yourself here http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org Same with the choices â€“ since we are not sandbox â€“ we canâ€™t change the history. We are trying to improve replayability by different Prologue settings, adding interesting achievements and working on Steam Workshop where we want to allow the players make the own history.

If you have any questions or ideas please share it with us here http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/350544272221845683/ 

Thanks!

review:
Like it.

So the main storyline is always the same -- since it's based on REAL HISTORY -- , but there are random events which do influence your civilization, etc. 
You can actually influence difficulty alot (start of the game). 
Also like the drawing style and overview,

Great Indie Game for about 4 hours on a run

author: {'steamid': '76561198107121003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482850536}
review: Linear and boring after first game
developer_response:
Hi! Thanks for the review, it will help us to make future games even better.

The game is linear because this is a true story of Pre-Dynastic Egypt, we are unable to step away from it at the expense of historicity. The real city reconstruction http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org â€“ there are excavations there, on the same map that you see in the game. It is one of the strongest features in the game, because all information you found in the game endorsed by the scientists and Egyptologists.

And you can share with us your ideas how to make the game interesting http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/350544272221845683/

author: {'steamid': '76561197999213780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1522390682}
review:
I love this game.  It does something I've always wanted to see done in a Civ style game in how it starts at a much smaller scope and 'zooms' out about the mid point.  It's the same mechanic, and you can still zoom back in.  But that's a big deal to me.  A wonderful way to do exploration games, and keep things just as focused as tech increases.

Add to that the fun little historical/archaeological vignettes?  And this is a winner.  I love it.  I also want more.  And a Babylon one!

author: {'steamid': '76561197995312112', 'num_games_owned': 302, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1482699525}
review:
Purchased this during the Steam Winter Sale of 2016. Now, I don't really have anything bad to say about the gameplay to be honest. It reminded me a lot of a game I really enjoyed back in the day which I think was called "Cleopatra".

However, after about 2 hours of playing it I think I was around 50% through the entire game, even if it's enjoyable a roughly 4 hour game isn't worth the time, not to mention that it lacks any replay value to speak of.

Basically it's the exact same map, the exact same events happen, there is not much choice and you cannot pick yourself which spots you want to improve and so forth. There is VERY little in terms of choice in this game in general. Which really doesn't help with the utter lack of replayability.

Good concept, I enjoyed the artistic style quite a bit, the historical accuracy, the music and so forth but it's far too short, too restrictive, not enough choices, limits you to 200 turns (which go by fast) and holds the players hand far too much.

As it is now, I'd give it like a 5/10. If they add more options and make it longer then I'd say it'd be worth the cash for sure. If you're buying it for a sibling or say one of your kids around the age of 8-12 then I'd give it a 7/10 due to the learning aspect of it.
developer_response:
Greetings! Thanks for your opinion, even if itâ€™s a bad one. We hope it will help us to make better games in future.

Letâ€™s me answer your questions since our game is different from others and I was possibly why you had such comments.

Our game is not like usual sandbox games or games you playing in historical setting (like Civ series or Total War or name any game like this). All information you found in the game and game story is based on real history of Predynastic Egypt approved by professional scientists and Egyptologists. The map you are complaining about â€“ is a real map of ancient Hierakonpolis with reconstructed buildings. You can check the excavation site yourself here http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org Same with the choices â€“ since we are not sandbox â€“ we canâ€™t change the history. We are trying to improve replayability by different Prologue settings, adding interesting achievements and working on Steam Workshop where we want to allow the players make the own history. And regarding the price â€“ you think game with such deep content must cost less than movie ticket?

If you have any questions or ideas please share it with us here http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/350544272221845683/ 

Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561198100277660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2470, 'last_played': 1579443405}
review:
This is my first review on Steam :)

I wasn't sure if I should recommend this or not. It was a bit of a tough call. 

It was kind of nice, but there are too many negative aspects of the game. 

The buildings all have set places, research just upgrade the existing tiles. but you have no control over how to shape the city at all. 

There is no sandbox or even campaign, just one very short story. which can be finished in about 2-3 hours, you can play it again but there will be NOTHING new, the exact same thing. 
It's like it's just one level of a game, I'd spent more time on levels other games than I did to play this twice!

I even expected way more history and info about egypt, like what was in the Children of the Nile. But it barely has any info at all. 

Really the game play is very limited, short, lacks depth and story. 
but still, I did enjoy it for 20 hours or so.
developer_response:
Thanks for the review. Any opinion is helping us make the better games in future. 

About sandbox and story - It is a true story of the Predynastic Egypt, and we cannot sacrifice history t the usual sandbox game â€“ the basic idea was to show you the real history of ancient Egypt. The city is real http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org - There's an excavation on the same map you see in the game. It is one of the most powerful features in our game, because all the information you find in the game has been approved by scientists and Egyptologists (there was none in Children of the Nile btw).
To make the game longer - we made Prologue settings and allowed to play after the end of the campaign. We already working on Steam Workshop that will allow us to improve replay value even more. Sorry that you had such experience, please if you have any suggestions how to improve the game - send it to us to clarusvictoria@gmail.com or write it here http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/350544272221845683 . By the way - It seems you spend already 6+ hours in the game : ) Thanks!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970369196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 860, 'last_played': 1483373625}
review:
Itâ€™s like a simplified Civilization with a single civ and a single scenario based on real history, and a hand-drawn map. Drag workers to the places that give the most resources (workers arenâ€™t expended like in Civ), build improvements, conquer or unite other tribes. I find it less stressful than civ for some reason. You are unlikely to get conquered on easier levels, but you may fail the endgame unless you manage to unify all the 15 tribes along the Nile, build a new capital city, unify the religions and hold a great feast (each subgoal requiring several thousands of one the 4 basic resources) by turn 220. You can play through it once in one evening, and then try a harder difficulty next time.

Highly recommended. It made me long for the old Ceasar and Pharao games through.

review: å§æ§½ï¼Œè¿ç»­3æ¬¡219å›åˆå‹çº¿å¬´ï¼Œæœ€åçš„å­Ÿè²æ–¯åŸçœŸæ˜¯æŠŠæˆ‘çš„ç”Ÿäº§åŠ›æ¦¨å¾—ä¸€å¹²äºŒå‡€

author: {'steamid': '76561198034329440', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1511371208}
review:
What a game!  My playthrough lasted less than 4 hours, but my god!  I have never had such a pure, distilled experience of what I love most in 4x games, like Civ, Crusader Kings 2, and Europa Universalis: growing my civilization from nothing to see it shine.  This is something I have wanted someone to tackle for so long!  From a tiny village of nothing, I built the Egyptian Kingdom, in the perfect level of detail.  Early farms gave way to great irrigation projects; primitive shrines became great temple projects; chieftains' heirs were pharoahs with great tombs; petty rival tribes gave way to great ones; and my tiny village became a great city ruling an empire.

Unfortunately, I don't think that there'll be much replay value to get me to play it a second time (it's scripted, not proceedurally generated), but it's still 100% worth it.  Other games last forever, and you come back to them again and again.  This one is a short burst of euphoria, at least if this experience is something you want.

Thank you, Clarus Victoria.  Now I need to look at your older games, to see if you've got anything similar.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009903018', 'num_games_owned': 1297, 'num_reviews': 325, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1482540443}
review:
A fine "little" game: I mean, I recommend it, but maybe on sale.
The game itself is funny, but really short for a sim/strategy game and the main problem is that I don't see much replaibility.
One game, and you are ok: the design of the game is very straight, don't allow much changes from game to game.

Overall, a fine game, but a bit overpriced.

review:
Nettes kleines Indie-Strategiespiel mit historischem Bezug zum alten Ã„gypten. Das Spiel thematisiert die Entwicklung Ã„gyptens vor den Pharaonen

Pro:
+ historische Geschichte Ã„gyptens vor der Pharaonenzeit
+ schlichte aber hÃ¼bsche Grafik
+ zu allen Forschungen und GebÃ¤uden gibt es Hintergrundinformationen nach aktuellem Forschungsstand
+ Spielerische Freiheiten in den Entscheidungen, z.B. Diplomatie oder Krieg.
+ Entscheidungen haben immer Auswirkungen auf das fortlaufende Spiel

Contra:
- Wiederspielwert ist gering wegen historischen Ereignissen die immer auftreten (man weiÃŸ was kommt).
- Startbedingungen haben nur geringen Einfluss
- Zum Ende hin wird es hektisch, man muss schnell alle Bedingungen fÃ¼r den Sieg erfÃ¼llen. Die ersten 80-90% sind gemÃ¤chliches und bedachtes handeln Spielen, die letzten 10-20% wirkten auf mich wie im Zeitraffer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007832600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1710949138}
review:
Just like their other games Pre-Civilization Marble Age and Bronze Age, this one is a gem. It is balanced, bug-free and beautiful with good replayability potential. Although, the replayability isn't about changing the story - the story and the flow of the game does not change. It is about bettering one's previous performance, trying to get get gold victories at every challenge and so forth.

Two thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198026240068', 'num_games_owned': 763, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 6999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 823, 'last_played': 1694624632}
review:
As someone who has been playing Clarus Victoria games since they were little 1.99 apps, I really got excited when I saw this on Steam (I also noticed Steam now has their previous game, Marble Age, which I spent plenty of hours pulling my hair out over on my iPad). 

This is one of those games that does the 'easy to learn, hard to master' concept justice. On beginner's difficulty, this game is almost insultingly easy--and a playthrough shouldn't take you more than 1-1.5 hours to beat. Where is gets hard is when you start taking off the training wheels. It's hard to say what gives this game so much replayability--the maps are more or less the same and outside of some unexpected events, you'll be playing the same thing every time. Yet the more you play, the more you realize how every. single. tiny. action will have repercussions down the road. You'll have to start preparing for events several turns ahead of you, and even after you've played through a few times and you know what's coming, it's surprisingly tricky to actually prepare properly to actually avoid things cleanly. 

I've put in a solid number of hours in this game and I still haven't been able to win on difficult with all of the achievements, and that's saying something considering how deceptively easy it felt in the beginning. Definitely give this game a shot, at the very least it will be a very engaging few hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008838869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1481881105}
review:
Stumbled upon the game by coincidence and a YT review from Writing Bull...and I am a big fan after the first round I played. It is a great way of getting an inside to ancient Egypt and thus the dawn of civilization. For me the replayability is high as there is always something to be improved, despite the game basically following a similar path each time. For the knowledge and fun this game provides, the price is way to low.

If you look for a short game to intelligently entertain you...this is it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009963057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1483630395}
review:
Won the first game two rounds before the finish line. *yay*

I yet have to test the replay value, but you get a solid strategy game for the money. You have to balance food, production and overall growth, later on military and religion. Although the gameplay is easy to comprehend, it gets more complex with each advancement.
Especially when the world map is added as an second level. How much focus do you keep on your city and how much on exploration and cunquest?

The graphics do their job, nothing more, nohting less.

It is defiintnely NO Civilization or Pharaoh (for those who remember), but it isn't a casual game either. In addition you get some information on ancient Egypt or stone / brinze culture in general. So, yep, worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007831648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2941, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1665509793}
review:
Vraiment sympa ! Jeu de gestion tour par tout qui fait penser Ã  Civilization dans certains aspects. C'est un jeu mais avec Ã©normement de rejouabilitÃ©.

On revit l'histoire de l'Egypte prÃ©-dynnastique, c'est donc des parties Ã  nombres de tours prÃ©dÃ©finis (230+-), on revit les mÃªmes Ã©venements majeurs et on rejoue sur la mÃªme map mais ce ne retire rien au plaisir du jeu, que du contraire. (l'emplacement des ressources varie).

On gagne des ressoucres Ã  chaque tour (5 diffÃ©rentes +-) et on peut allouer des ouvriers sur des secteurs (une case) afin de gagner les ressources de ces derniÃ¨res. (tel Civilization)
On peut bien sur construire, entrainer des troupes et faire des "recherches technnologiques" en consommant les ressources correspondantes.

Le but de la partie est de rÃ©ssurir Ã  unir l'Egypte via 6 objectifs majeurs qui seront encore une fois toujours les mÃªmes mais c'est justement la que la rejouabilitÃ© prend son sens car ce n'est pas si facile et micro-gerer chaque tour devient vite essentiel la oÃ¹ dans un Civ on clique assez souvent sur "prochain tour" sans mÃªme regarder.

Plusieurs malus sont disponibles pour corsser la difficultÃ©, pas de multi, on joue avec/contre l'IA mais il faut plus voir une partie comme un scÃ©nario oÃ¹ l'IA joue un second rÃ´le car vous faites, en rÃ©alitÃ©, une course contre la montre ou il faut gerer au mieux vos ouvriers/techno/construction pour produire toujours plus et remplir les objectifs majeurs au plus tÃ´t.

Il est possible de continuer la partie aprÃ¨s l'Ã©cheance des 220 tours, systÃ¨me de points (score) Ã  la fin.

On peut parler d'un mix Pharaon/Civ, simple mais vraiment sympa, je conseille Ã  tous les fans de gestion.

Environ 3 heures pour finir une partie en easy (avec les 4 bonus du dÃ©but) mais l'objectif final reste difficile Ã  atteindre.
