author: {'steamid': '76561198118910889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1590351429}
review:
Aufmerksam geworden bin ich auf dieses Spiel durch eine Let's Play-Vorstellung durch den Let's Player Writing Bull, danke fÃ¼rs Vorstellen an der Stelle, und es hat mir spontan gefallen.

Pre-Dynastic Egypt ist ein nettes kleines rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel. Es stammt von russischen Indie-Entwicklern, die bereits, soweit ich das erkennen kann, Spiele dieser Machart fÃ¼r die klassische Antike und die Steinzeit gemacht haben und das Szenario diesmal ins Alte Ã„gypten verlegt haben. Es orientiert sich ein bisschen an Civ, konzentriert sich aber hauptsÃ¤chlich auf einen Aspekt der Spiele nÃ¤mlich die BÃ¼rgerverwaltung. Rundenweise erwirtschaften wir durch das Einsetzen von BÃ¼rgern auf verschiedenen Ressourcen-Feldern eben diese verschiedenen Ressourcen, um neue BÃ¼rger auszubilden, GebÃ¤ude zu bauen, die die ErtrÃ¤ge steigern und kulturelle Errungenschaften freizuschalten, die uns Boni geben oder neue GebÃ¤ude oder Features freischalten.

Die Grafik ist eher zweckmÃ¤ÃŸig aber in einem liebevoll an Ã¤gyptische Malereien angelehnten Stil gehalten und im Vergleich zu seinen direkten VorgÃ¤ngern sieht es auch weniger aus wie ein Mobile-Game, dafÃ¼r sorgt allein schon die sehr stimmige Gesamtkonzeption. Ein Ã¼briges tut dazu dann auch noch der sehr passende Soundtrack, der bei mir sofort wohlige Erinnerungen an den City-Builder Pharaoh von damals auslÃ¶st. Also in der Beziehung kann man nicht meckern. Das Spiel ist komplett und soweit ich Ã¼berschauen kann auch sehr gut Ã¼bersetzt worden und bindet angesichts des historischen Szenarios auch begleitend zur eigenen Entwicklung und dem historischen Background Infohappen ein, die eben diese geschichtliche Epoche erlÃ¤utern. Dabei hat der Entwickler wohl entsprechend mit Historikern zusammengearbeit, um da historisch akkurat zu sein, was diese Infohappen angeht. Valiant Hearts lÃ¤sst ein wenig grÃ¼ÃŸen.

Da man sich sehr an einem halbwegs historischen Geschichtsverlauf orientiert ist es die Aufgabe des Spiel entlang eines gescripteten historischen Kampagne verschiedene historische Stationen der predynastischen-Ã¤gyptischen Zeit nachzuerleben und vom Nomadenstamm Ã¼ber eine sesshafte Tonbrenner-Kultur Ã¼ber Adels- und Stadtgesellschaft hin zum frÃ¼hen vereinten Ã¤gyptischen Reich aufzusteigen. Dabei werden zu bestimmten Zeiten (neben Runden bemisst sich der Spielfortschritt entsprechend auch mit einem Zeitfortschritt) historische Ereignisse wie die Verehrung des Falken als Hauptgott, der Krieg der frÃ¼hen Ã¤gyptischen Kulturzentren oder der Ã¤gyptische BÃ¼rgerkrieg, der es in Unter- und OberÃ¤gypten teilte als PrÃ¼fungen getriggert, die man entsprechend Ã¼berstehen und auch rechtzeitig abschlieÃŸen muss, um die eigentlich zentralen Siegbedingungen zu erfÃ¼llen, nÃ¤mlich die Einigung Ã„gyptens dann in einem gemeinsamen Reich.

Zwischendurch verbringen wir eben viel Zeit damit unsere Anfangssiedlung rundenweise zu optimieren, zunÃ¤chst die regionale Karte aufzudecken, umliegende StÃ¤mme zu unterwerfen oder einzugliedern und damit zum FÃ¼rstentum zu werden, um so die globale Ã„gyptische Karte freizuschalten, auf der wir dann ganz Ã¤hnlich dann mit fremden Kulturzentren handeln, sie anschlieÃŸen oder mit ihnen Krieg fÃ¼hren. Zwischendurch gibt es immer mal wieder negaitve oder positive Zufallsereignisse, die einem Boni bringen oder Kosten auflergen kÃ¶nnen.

Das Spiel ist auf etwa 220 - 230 Runden gedeckelt. Sprich es ist keine uferlose Erfahrung, wie man sie vielleicht von manchen Civ-Partien kennt. Innerhalb dieser Rundenzahl mÃ¼ssen wir entsprechend die finale PrÃ¼fung, die Einigung des Reiches abgeschlossen haben, die dann im Lategame sowohl Kultur(Forschungs)punkte, als auch Produktion als auch Nahrung im groÃŸen Stil verschlingt, also sollte man bis zur heiÃŸen Phase gut in seine Wirtschaft investiert haben. Ich habe fÃ¼r einen erste Durchlauf etwa 4h Stunden auf der einfachste Schwierigkeit gebraucht und muss sagen, dass es trotzdem nach hinten raus mit der PrÃ¼fung eng wurde. Also ich hatte bei jeder PrÃ¼fung noch ein paar Runden Luft nach oben und hab die recht gut abgeschlossen (es gibt Wertungen dafÃ¼r uA wie schnell man sie abschlieÃŸen kann) aber das ist dennoch sehr passgenau mit den Runden gestrickt. Ich hatte das GefÃ¼hl sehr gut zu sein und der Zeit etwas voraus, aber tatsÃ¤chlich lag ich eigentlich so ziemlich genau immer auf der Erwartung. Also man muss schon ranklotzen. Ich kann mir vorstellen, dass auf hÃ¶heren Schwierigkeitsgraden die Zeit dann eben gerade genau ausreichen wird. Ich kann sagen das wenige Geld, dass ich fÃ¼r das spiel bezahlt habe, war diese vier stunden Erstspielzeit wirklich wert. Wiederspielwert ist ehrlich gesat nicht so klar zu benennen. Es gibt nur diese historische Kampagne, die man nach dem Abschluss quasi sandboxig weiterspielen kÃ¶nnte, was aber keinen Sinn macht, da danach nichts mehr passiert. Und die historische Kampagne spielt sich halt jedes Mal im Grunde gleich und die Karten sind ebenfalls identisch, sodass man, wenn man weis wo lukrative Vorkommen sind, dann die Erkundung direkt schon darauf fokussiert.

Der grÃ¶ÃŸte Wiederspielwert liegt eher in den Zufallsevents die noch mal eine besondere Erschwernis darstellen und eben im hÃ¶heren Schwierigkeitsgrad, wo man wahrscheinlich eben sein Vorwissen, Ã¼ber das, was kommt, oder was man aufdecken wird, gut gebrauchen kann. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad lÃ¤sst sich Ã¼ber Modifikatoren in gut, neutral oder schlecht in vier Bereichen bestimmen. Unter anderem die BodenqualitÃ¤t oder die HÃ¤ufigkeit bestimmter Ereignisse. StandardmÃ¤ÃŸig fÃ¼r Einsteiger steht das auf gut, das heiÃŸt man erhÃ¤lt kleine Boni auf die GelÃ¤ndeertrÃ¤ge oder hÃ¤ufiger positive Ereignisse. Auf neutral ist es entsprechend ausgeglichen und auf schwer erhÃ¤lt man Mali. Da man die vier Bereiche unabhÃ¤ngig von einander definieren kann, kann man sich die Schwierigkeit entsprechend individuell zusammenstellen, zum Beispiel zwar mehr negative Ereignisse aber keine Nachteile oder vielleicht Vorteile noch bei der Produktion. Das und die Zufallsevents lohnen dann eventuell die Kampagne nochmal als Herausforderung nochmals anzugehen. Da sie mit vier Stunden Spielzeit eben nicht sonderlich lang ist, kann man das auch gerne mal machen.

Wichtiger Punkt: Das Spiel erstellt zum Abschluss jeder gespielten Kampagne eine Punktewertung, die eben davon abhÃ¤ngt, wie schnell man die einzelnen PrÃ¼fungen jeweils abgeschlossen hat und auch welchen Schwierigkeitsgrad man zuvor eingestellt hat. So muss man, um das Spiel mit einer hÃ¶heren Punktzahl abzuschlieÃŸen, zwangslÃ¤ufig auf hÃ¶heren Schwierigkeitsgraden spielen.

Da das ganze noch mit Steam-Achievements unterlegt ist, sprich man auch noch einen Nachweis fÃ¼r den perfekten Playtrough bekommt, kann das nochmal sehr motivierend sein.

Insgesamt wurde ich fÃ¼r mein Geld da sehr gut unterhalten und kann das fÃ¼r Freunde von Rundenstrategie und BÃ¼rgermanagement bedenkenlos weiterempfehlen. Und werde wahrscheinlich bei Zeiten auch noch eine weitere Partie anfangen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009383387', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1481678166}
review:
Once again I wish steam would allow me to pick a 'meh' rating for a game.  This game is OK.  I did get it cheap, so I guess I can't really complain.

The big problem with this game is that there are absolutly no interesting decisions to be made.  You just plod along, waiting for stuff to happen.

It also throws scripted events at you, which are just annoying obsticals, like, build this thing in 10 turns, or a bunch of cities will just rebel.  There is no real warning for these these events and unless you have a large stack of resources sitting around, it can be problematic.

I guess I got my money's worth considering the price, but the game has no replay value and is entirely forgettable.

çŸ­å¤„:

- æ¸¸æˆåæœŸå› ä¸ºå„ç§éšæœºäº‹ä»¶,èµ„æºç®¡ç†ä¼šæœ‰äº›éº»çƒ¦

I received the key for free as a tester for the Chinese localization.I really appreciate the effort that the devs have made to make localizations for Chinese and several other languages.

The game is not very visually appealing, but it really surprises me with decent gameplay mechanics and serious history presentation. 

Pros: 
+ Good game mechanics, could be additive for the first few playthroughs
+ Real history of ancient Egypt
+ Easy to start but hard to master
+ Support multiple languages 

Cons:
- This game aims to present exact history, therefore, it will be a bit repetitive after the 1st playthrough
- End-game resource management is hard due to random events
- Graphics/UI is not very appealing (as my friend complains)

12.10. æ›´æ–°è¯„è®º:

12.10. Review Update:
After the new beta update, I tried the game once on the lowest difficulty and once on the hardest difficulty. (I realized that I have no idea how to win under those conditions tbh). 

During testing, I found the testers very enthusiatic. The devs has taken many suggestions from the community, including mine in the recent update. The gameplay experience now (especially for Chinese) is obviously much better than the last patch. Job well done and please continue with the good work.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972579966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1480485193}
review: So glad they resolved their name issue. This game is a great deal of fun and now it's BACK on Steam! Very strategic and tactical. The game looks simple but it has a depth for strategy games that makes me feel like a much less micro-managy version of Total War. No need to deal with individual units, let the game play out and bring Egypt into a prosperous setting! Very fun! (And yes, I may only have 2.3 hrs of playtime currently but that will be rising).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035651561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 2907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2562, 'last_played': 1558794801}
review: A great fast paced game, very addictive.  It's easy to master the basics but extremely hard to achieve total mastery of the game without considerable thought and pre-planning.  The key seems to be anticipating when the challenges (during which you score points) will occur.  A blast to play.

review:
Has everything a good civilization game needs: resource gathering, settlements, army building, technology research, and conflicting religions.

Just finished my first play-through, which took two-and-a-half hours on the easiest settings.  I failed about a quarter of the events.  But now that I know what to expect, it should be a lot easier.  Fortunately, there are multiple options for increasing the difficulty.

The replayability doesn't come from random maps, but rather from improving your performance on each set event and finally winning the game.  To me, it feels more like a "let's do better this time" game rather than a "what will happen this time" game.  And that's quite alright by me.

But the graphics and music are entirely fitting for the setting.  The music never got annoying.  Everything was easy to identify and the UI worked well.  I particularly liked the interludes that gave detail on certain events or places relevant to Egyptian history.

If you're interested in this time period, you'll have fun and maybe learn something.  If you're an expert on this time period, please let me know if the game got anything wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992930564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4499, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1426, 'last_played': 1638788236}
review:
A perfect example of small team indie development done right.

For an extremely simple and relatively short strategy game, the depth and re-playablity of Predynastic Egypt is remarkable. Definitely worth the entry fee.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002892819', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1507056369}
review:
What I like about this game:

1) Turn based gameplay. It allows you to plan ahead without rushing.
2) Numbers, numbers, numbers.
3) Civ like clone, which serves the game well.
4) Egypt and history is a great combination.

What the game lacks:

1) Replay value. There are only 3 difficulities and 1 scenario.

Conclusion - overall a good solid game for the current price. 7 out of 10 stars. Buy this product if you like Civilization type games and don't have a lot of money to spend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054309757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1478987773}
review:
Mixed feelings about this one. It is not really a game per se as the devs have put so much history into it and built a framework of 'play' that makes this more of a re-enactment than a normal free flowing game. Whilst I don't regret my purchase, I can't see myself playing this for long (I've actually had enough now at 16hrs, or coming back to it in the short term) because it has one overwhelmingly terminal flaw for me. So, the pros and cons: 

Pro's: 
Looks nice enough for what it is (a computerised board game is a good description), but it's clean, crisp and nice to look at.
Super easy to use interface and easy to pick up what you need to do.
Hard to master what you need to do (this is also a negative, see below).
Price, for â‚¬9, can't go wrong can you ???
It's stable, I had no glitches, freezes, CTD and/or bugs I could see.
The map randomises a little so most villages and resources may move around which mixes things up a little.
The game creates an environment where you have to carefully balance a number of resources and the actual balance point of the mix varies alot throughout the game.
You cannot 'win' this game by sitting back, building up a mega-blob army of wonder warriors and then blitzing the Nile valley in the last 5 turns, you actually have to think about things.

Con's:
Only one really - it's linear gameplay. You have many options and things to do on any given turn, but if you want to complete the challenges with their strict and short time limits (that always appear on the same game turn each game) you basically have to follow an optimal path to victory - if you wander off this path even a little for more than a few turns - challenges failed. Each challenge failed you incur a penalty or lose a bonus that then makes the rest of the game incrementally more difficult. So pressure is on to not fail ANY challenges.


Foreknowledge of challenges is often required to accomplish them - for example you must know that soon you will be asked to build a certain building in a certain location. That location is occupied by a friendly but neutral village. It takes 5 turns to convince them to join you (assuming you have the insane resource needed) or 5 turns to raid them and then another 5 to attack and kill them, plus of course the 5 turns to build the building while the challenge gives you 7 turns to do this - maybe you'll get lucky and a god will help out a little, but basically you needed to be ready to go beforehand, having stayed in that optimal linear position (pre-explored the right area and pre-dealt with the village and stockpiled or be producing enough resource to build the building), in order to accomplish this challenge.

Naturally I messed it up the first time through, but each subsequent run down the same path lets you get more familiar with it and hence further down the path before you stumble and fall. Not usually a good thing in gaming.

In short - yeah it's a good casual strategy game, gets you thinking and stressing over what to do next so I do recommend it especially for the price. I am guessing you'll probably play it a few times until you 'win' , then walking down the same path for yet another 200 turns to do the same things at the same time in largely the same regions will lose it's appeal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075098342', 'num_games_owned': 753, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1486410277}
review:
Played 2.5 hours non-stop as soon as downloading it.

So, first impressions... Totally worth the price. Most of the games these days have expensive price tags on them with no gameplay or fun at all. With that little money, you can buy Pre-Civilization Egypt and [b]make the Egypt great again.[/b]

My previous experience with Pre-Civilization series was with Marble Age. I had fun with it too so I didn't even hesitate to buy this. And it is much more better. 2 map design with detailed army numbers (and in-war bar) is giving the game better gameplay. I didn't try to befriend with others but well... It would be fun too I suppose. Quests are logical and doable. Research is WONDERFUL. In every strategy game that involves civilizations, I always want some improvement like that and finally got it. Improving my civilization in the way I want makes me feel in control and i liked it.

Besides, having multiple level choice at the start is really good. It is way better than chosing between easy/normal/hard only and having the options of chosing details.

Great game! Totally recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031383415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1634, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1499812245}
review: definitely worth to try out, even though the timeline is totally linear, and you won't play it more than 2-5 times. the story, the atmosphere, the game mechanics and the low price make it a must have for any strategy player!

author: {'steamid': '76561198027284352', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1478477451}
review: Surprisingly addictive, did not mean to sit here playing it for hours. Has a similar quality to Civilization but distinct enough gameplay that it doesn't feel like a rehash of old strategies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035921036', 'num_games_owned': 488, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1485893461}
review:
Another good game following pre-Civilization Marble Age (PCMA) which revolved around the history of Ancient/Medieval Greece -  I managed to beat  that one  but no luck with this baby yet.

As with PCMA, you get to take control of a fledgling civilization from the pre-historic times to the crucial times in world history. This game is akin to Civilization, but unlike Civ, you don't get tied in micromanagement - instead they use the Toynbee model of historical development: you get a new historical challenge from time to time (form a tribe, hold out against the followers of another agressive Egyptian deity, find a route to the Middle East to build a pyramid, etc.) and overcoming those challenges is essentially winning. 

Yeah, you get to do some resource management and construction planning, but the big picture and overall historical landscape is far more important and weighing your decisions is likely to take more of your time than implementing them - no driving throngs of stack of units around the map, no conquering gazillions of enemy cities or building up tonnes of units to defend your many cities. Everything's more laid back, schematic and easy to manage, grand strategy style. 

The overall look and feel is similar to that of PCMA, but I'd say it looks like that only on the surface - the whole gameplay (religion, minor tribes, combat) are very different and I'd say improved. What both games have in common is the pre-determined historical flow of events and the depth of detail - they call it "story-rich" nowadays - you really feel that you are making history here, from the first farm to the first Mastaba. While some local tribes and starting conditions are randomized, the game itself is not random - you WILL follow the path of the Egyptian civilization. Or die trying.

All in all, I love these two games because they manage to be educational without actually being boring as hell, like most of these types do, not to mention that they require attention to detail, thinking and planning. Easy to learn the basics, they are quite difficult to beat - so replayability is very high.

From my prospective, this developer has some serious potential. This game is fresh, it's not like anything else I've seen recently. Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056544350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1478442405}
review:
Imagine a simpler Civilization game, where you can only play one civilization (I wonder which that is...) but with all the addictive properties and balanced complexity. An excellent game. The learning curve is great - you can either play at an easy level and simply enjoy the ambiance and the history, allowing you to experiment and try new things out; or you can try the more challenging settings and really try and make every turn count.

The art is great, simple enough that it doesn't distract the player away from the gameplay, but good enough to make the game feel professionally done.                 

TLDR: I really like this game. Each game is only about an hour to two long (at my personal pace), but it's good enough to keep you starting new games over and over again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113245987', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 942, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 332, 'last_played': 1708924736}
review: Not nearly as good as the previous game, get Pre Civilization: Marble Age instead. It gets rid of all the core mechanics of the series, has significantly less content, and is just plain boring.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261455388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1496866602}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042765728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 168866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1125, 'last_played': 1673348161}
review:
Pre-Civilization Egypt is a fun little strategy game that can be finnished over the course of an hour or so depending on how fast you play.

Control-wise it is just a matter of clicking and dragging your worker cards onto field that have to be worked/explored/etc... Very simple to understand tough, I also recommend new players to use the tutorial and pay attention to the missions that are presented. Because those help a lot in finding your footing

The graphics are very simplistic, but fit really well with the theme of Ancient Egypt.

The replay value at first may not be the best because the game uses the same map every time with only slight variations on the spawn locations and yields. But seeing your score at the end of the game, you can definatly get hooked on the idea that: 'you can do better'

The different difficulty settings (which are also bound to your end score) also add more variety by making the game easier or harder in different aspects.

If you have the cash on hand, and want a game that requires a decent amount of strategy and planning ability, you might be interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028963911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1478539711}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029648342', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 2537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 363, 'last_played': 1581493696}
review:
Fun and addicting. I tend to have trouble not playing through a whole game in one sitting. I'm happy to say I've increased my score each time.

Hint: the game awards raw aggression, unlike civ, etc.

My one complaint is unclean late game goals. My last playthough I missed out on winning because I didn't realize I had to build up to the last city and I thought I had to control more allied cities (Unite vs ally).

author: {'steamid': '76561198035635524', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 171, 'playtime_forever': 1284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 309, 'last_played': 1648401788}
review:
Very lovely! makes me feel like I am managing my own ancient eypgtian civ from the ground up, I can recommend this game in its current state.  No bugs that I know off.  Neat goals and it has a bit of a learning curve but not too difficult to figure it out. Can be challenging even after when the game ends, you can still 'continue' so the game dont just end there

if you like what you see and read from this review. Id say its well worth your money, for Â£5.99 - I think its fanatastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045401832', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 191, 'playtime_forever': 1486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1556318543}
review: What a wonderful historical simulation. Although it may LOOK like a Civ wanna-be at first glance, it actually has different mechanics and is actually historically accurate. I watched a Youtube playthrough by some Dad Gamer, and was sold on it, since some of the reviews here complained about replay value. From what I could tell, there are a bunch of challenge modes and scoring to replay. There are random events and numbers to keep you honest with each and every playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166787207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 505, 'last_played': 1711126086}
review: I was a fan of Marble Age. This? This just makes it better. It takes a lot of mechanics - From exploration, to resource gathering, to invasion. (No wonder it has Pre-Civilization in the title) One of the only problems I have with it is that it is a tiny bit too hard. Maybe it is just me, but even on easy mode, it feels like the final trial is so hard. This is supposed to be a game that is historic to real Egypt. The cons might seem bad, but there are so many good mechanics. I don't want to spoil this good game, (I don't know what there is to spoil) so if you are interested in history or Marble Age, grab this amazing game. It's worth the $9.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989330859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1478131375}
review:
If you like pre-civ games, your going to love this one too! 

The games basically play as turn based strat "mini" games (a good hour or so) but there are goals to meet so replayability is a sure thing as you try to best yourself over and over. 

I had a bit of an issue getting my copy to work originally but support were super awesome and quick to get back to me, even on a weekend. 
Issue is game was failing to launch, but it was a mear windows issue as a reboot fixed it. 

Rach.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040541359', 'num_games_owned': 1725, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1519423220}
review:
Interesting little strategy game, With very nice graphics - short however. If You are a fan of
turn base games yes - It totally had the just-one-more-turn curse! You have been warned!

You will probably get from two to three playthroughs out of it so for a coffee breaker game I would say its a good score. This is not starcraft where AMP is critical. You can relax and even learn a thing or two as the game is history base. Keep in mind this game may wreck You in the beginning before You understand its basics! So don't give up and replay it as its worth to play it.

Pre-Civilization Egypt may also remind a lot of people of Pharos or Cleopatra a very good old city builder game set in egypt. But here we have to rule an entire kingdom of egypt at some point. You play as a small tribe whose destiny is to reunite the egypt in to one empire! Here You will learn a little bit about the culture and the cults of ancient egypt, aswell as Conflicts. Create beliefs, build wonders attack or make other tribes join You - Events are scraped so You can save/load cheat Your way around but that does not mean the game is bad. If You are a perfectionist player is better for You if not - then You will simply ignore it. Tho some of them are done a way where You have to do exactly what to do otherwise accept You failed.

Pre-Civilization Egypt is a very good game I would say if You like small games its a must have, if You like Civilization turn-type games its a must have, if you have any interest in Egypt history its a must have.


If You prefer to watch somebody play it I made a video of Pre-Civilization Egypt so feel free to check it out:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWqkz7jcZgg

author: {'steamid': '76561198030160135', 'num_games_owned': 359, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 815, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1495312646}
review: This game is great, pretty, well researched and challenging. It will provide you with 1 - 3 complete playthroughs (the story is linear) but it has great value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970716267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 17825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 41, 'playtime_at_review': 1534, 'last_played': 1711291940}
review: Alright so I have played this game far too much. It is simple and it is addictive. However, it is appallingly frustrating. The game often punishes success. "Oh you have a massive army?" * Your commander has been killed, Your troops hesitate. Your troops flee the battlefield* "Oh you have lots of production? *A number of your workshops have been damaged*. I don't mind hard. I do mind cheating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975254954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1477300728}
review: Pretty interesting strategy game. Nice theme and graphics. Relatively short play time and limited replayability, unless one really wants to perfect their score. Many "scripted" events that you can't work around, which sort of require you to know how they work in advance to do well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018993869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 611, 'last_played': 1477263478}
review: Nice game, good atmosphere, for me it totally had the just-one-more-turn effect, but has low replay value. Also liked the fact that the game was quite challanging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056225633', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1477230736}
review:
3h game, map is always the same, so the replayability is about trying some strategic challenges ect. The game is beautiful and historically accurate, not over hard and not short neither. I enjoyed.

I personnally recommend the game, it is like playing a city managment of CIV V, building and moving workers to focus on one ressource or another. Worth the buy in discount for sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119848200', 'num_games_owned': 854, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1477079443}
review:
Pre-Civilization Egypt focuses on recreating a historical reenactment of early Egypt from the years 6000-4000 BCE. The game has a pleasant and distinct art style, reminiscent of table top games. The rules are easy enough to pick up withing fifteen minutes and each playthrough will probably take around 4 hours depending on difficulty and how familiar you are with the game's mechanics. 

The focus of the game is a historical timeline of Egypt but you manage the turn to turn efforts of growing the empire such as gathering food, building armies, worshiping gods, and trading with neighboring tribes. You'll have to improve your cities bu building land improvements and researching techs acquired through culture generation. 

The game can be quite brutal at anything but the lowest difficulty leading to the dev describing it as the Dark Souls of the Turn Based genre of games. 

In my opinion the price is reasonable and the gameplay solid, you'll probably get at least two playthroughs of this game completed before you loose interest. 

To hear more of my thoughts on the game and demo some gameplay please give my first impressions video a watch. 

https://youtu.be/oESWP5SPkao

author: {'steamid': '76561197964624484', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 624, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 624, 'last_played': 1477328603}
review:
A simple and yet excellent game that history, strategy and Civilization fans will most likely enjoy. I found the game interesting and challenging and I do hope to see more in this series if the developer can do as good a job as this. The game is certainly more linear than many similar titles, and may not have as much replay value once you have beaten it (though you can always try to do a better job or ramp up the difficulty) but other than I could not find anything negative.

Full gameplay details and more information in the video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=flr010zrL9E

author: {'steamid': '76561198053393456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1478633224}
review:
An extremely promising project. 
Considering devs' obviously scarce resources, they managed to maintain a perfect balance between playability and immersion in specific historical context (generally unknown to regular audience).
The biggest drawback is its lack of replayability. However, I'll surely try it at least once on another difficulty level. 

Surely worth buying, at least to support the devs and encourage them to improve the game further, as well as to develop new projects. Thank you, guys!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007850801', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1477079565}
review: A fun little game, takes about 2 to 3 hours to play start to finish. Why did I not recommend it? Well, even though it is fun, it is very linear and has no replay value. After you have played through once or maybe twice, it is a done deal. You know all the events, what will happen when and there is really no "play" or choice to it. This is really a half decent tablet game, good for killing a few hours on a plane, but not much more. If I had paid a couple of dollars for this I might give it higher marks, but it sells itself as a full fledge game and that it is not.
developer_response:
Thank you for your kind words, I see you have already played almost 9 hours? I hope you were satisfied, thatâ€™s why we created the variations different tactics of the strategical development.

Regarding the linearity â€“ here both, Yes and No. The game is linear because this is a true story of Pre-Dynastic Egypt, we are unable to step away from it at the expense of historicity. The real city reconstruction http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org â€“ there are excavations there, on the same map that you see in the game. It is one of the strongest features in the game, because all information you found in the game endorsed by the scientists and Egyptologists. How can a game with such depth cost less than a half of the burger?

author: {'steamid': '76561198055382375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 257, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 257, 'last_played': 1477157271}
review:
A very nice game. I love it. 
First of all you're learning and, at the same time, you can enjoy a strategic game based on a part of the arcaic ancient egyptian's history. 
Sure, this is not a Sid Meyer's Civilization game but i think, however, that is very original and ... I hope, in a not far future, to see around more games of this kind in the videogame industry. Very enjoyable and thoughtfull.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009965051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1657068212}
review:
Just as fun as the other Pre-Civilizations. It's not like the Sids games, it's more of a city- worker/resource manager with a grand strategy. You have milestones that you must hit along the way but you're faced with challenges and random events that can either help or hurt you. UI is great and easy to learn, and has enough depth to keep you interested. A play through takes about 1-2 hours, so you can get a good game in a short amount of time. Each playthrough you must choose 1 of 3 starting conditions out of 4 different categories, so you can have a couple of different play throughs each time with varying difficulties.

Unlike what others have said, the game is not broken or unbalanced. I was able to beat it the first time through on easy with out a problem, but I've played other Pre-civ games so I knew somewhat what to expect. If it's like the other games, then the devs will do a great job of balancing any issues found and fixing bugs as they come up. 

If you like this genre then I recommend the game, and it's a must buy if on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106975733', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 576, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1577166000}
review: I failed the unification of Egypt by ONE TURN. But yeah, this game is really awesome imo. It's only about 3-4 hours long but it's definitely got a lot of replayability. At least to an extent. There's a lot more options in terms of tactics and the scoring system gives you something to work towards. It kinda sucks that you can only play as one faction whereas in the previous game you could play as two, but it makes sense in terms of them staying true to the historical context. So yeah, great game! Definitely need a sequel

author: {'steamid': '76561198042147298', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 509, 'last_played': 1691485038}
review:
Tolles Spiel, dass trotz seiner Schlichtheit fesselt! Die Mechanik und das Wissen, dass jede Handlung EinfluÃŸ auf den Spielverlauf hat, ist toll. Auch die im Zeitverlauf auftretenden Herausforderungen verleihen dem Spiel WÃ¼rze. 
Die Kurzweiligkeit finde ich gut. Eine Runde Pre-Civilization Egypt dauert ca. 2 Stunden.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964815052', 'num_games_owned': 731, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 412, 'last_played': 1480378926}
review:
Play the flash predecessors here free: 
http://www.kongregate.com/games/clarusvictoria/pre-civilization-stone-age
http://www.kongregate.com/games/clarusvictoria/pre-civilization-bronze-age

This game is about REPEATED iterations... optimizing build orders... testing new strategies.

To everyone who played once and died and downvoted, DYING IS SUPPOSED TO HAPPEN.

You should start on EASY EASY EASY EASY. If you end your first game with 0 points, you are doing well.

You will get better.

Think of this game as a no-combat rogue-like.

Practice. Get better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171581301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1502048167}
review: Really fun strategy game, lots of challenging trials and interesting events. It's quite a short game in comparisson to old games like Pharaoh and Caesar, but it's also a quarter of the price they were new, so definitely well worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970344902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1516937653}
review:
This is a really solid improvement and blending of the themes in Bronze Age and Marble Age.

It's more professionally produced as well although the English translation from the Russian is a little formal and in need of further polish which to be fair it does seem to be getting.

The game is actually a fair bit more complicated than it looks, and more like a puzzle game, with a correct move to progress, than a strategy game. It uses those puzzels to tell the story of the founding of Egypt that will take about 4 hours to tell.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976327138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 1389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 977, 'last_played': 1653943273}
review: A nice little game that kind fo lacks replayability, but is well made interesting and fine for what it is.  kind fo like a flash game on steroids.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051546064', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1476849778}
review:
With Pre-Civilization Egypt, Clarus Victoria had an opportunity to take Pre-Civilization Marble Age forward. You generally expect a sequel to be at least as able as its predecessor, this is one step forward, two steps back. Instead of Warcraft I to Warcraft II to III, we see Hero of the Kingdom I become Hero of the Kingdom II - a stale rebake of a mediocre game. 

It feels unfinished, should be early access. The text interrupts are poorly written and detract rather than enhance. Extremely narrow strategic choices, inferior to Pre-Civilization Marble Age.  You have no access to any information and no options to control anything. No infopedia and no explanation of how much of the mechanics break down. You have no idea where construction will take place, until its built, and surprise it will be on certain preset tiles. Rather than Marble Age blossoming into a more sophisticated, interesting and complete game this is more like being delivered a still partly frozen pizza.

Worst of all, its frustrating rather than fun.
I do not recommend this, even on sale
developer_response:
Greetings, we are sad to see the negative review from a person who had previously offered his help http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/340412122402408016/. We would gladly have accepted it, and are ready to accept now, but unfortunately, there was no constructive dialogue. We want to continue this conversation, so we could find out exactly what You did not like and we want try to fix it. Could you please clarify some points?

Why exactly you feel this game is unfinished? â€“ We need to know the problem so we can solve it.

If you would like to suggest some text changes â€“ you can always write about it here http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/discussions/0/348292787748280901/ and weâ€™ll fix everything ASAP.

Regarding strategic choices and access to any information and control options â€“ can you please specify what do you mean?

We are already working on Egypt Wiki and the game guides you can find here http://steamcommunity.com/app/461620/guides/ and F.A.Q. â€“ here https://clarusvictoria.zendesk.com/  

Regarding construction places â€“ this is a historical strategy and the Hierakonpolis is one of the most famous excavation places http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org  of the pre-dynastic Egypt. This is one of our main features â€“ you are building the reconstructed city of Ancient Egypt on the reconstructed landscape. For example, the event â€œThe fire in potterâ€™s workshopâ€ with damaged workshop, the remains of which were found in the Hierakonpolis almost exactly in the same place on the map as in the game.

Also, the new update 1.0.1 is completely new experience if you had problems with game difficulty before.
Looking forward for your comments to improve the game more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074090428', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 407, 'last_played': 1476880535}
review:
I played the demo once, and I like the gameplay, so I decided to give it a try.

However, to my surprise, even at all easy setting, there is little to none margin for getting Gold on objectives. Finish Horus Temple in 34 turn or less? Good luck on that, except you're on the second playthrough AND you are lucky getting food and prod bonuses from exploration.
The same can be said for other objectives. On your first playthrough, you'll be frustrated with the minimum information of the next challenge.

This would not bother me if only I'm not a perfectionist and wanting to get all Gold achievements. Luckily, they provided a multi slot save games.

I enjoy the gameplay, but I agree with other reviewers, this has little replayability. I only completed the game once, and didn't want a second run, at least for a while.

There are a lot of things that can be improved, like right clicking to remove notification icons on the right, reducing the ridiculous amount of scouting needed on world map, cancelling diplomatic mission, and many more. But for now, the game is enjoyable, but don't expect "one-more-turn" like Civ.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023709903', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1295, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1636451006}
review: Eygpt has always been my favourite ancient civilisation, and to be able to play it at its founding was a blast. This game is challenging and it took me a few runs through to complete it even with the all starting bonuses, but everything works well and the concepts are easy to gasp. Good value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056418438', 'num_games_owned': 144, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1151, 'last_played': 1476617897}
review:
Wisst ihr, was mir bei diesem Spiel auf den Keks ging? Der unmenschlich schwere Anfang bis man irgendwann merkt "Ah.. wahrscheinlich mach ich was falsch". Da ich mich nach "Gold" gesehnt hatte habe ich das Spiel dreimal beendet mit den Worten "ja, dann fi*kt euch doch"

War aber so dumm, dass ich es wieder angemacht hatte. SchlieÃŸlich nach einem verlorenen Samstag und mit andauernd Ã¼berhitztem Gehirn habe ich die mittlere Schwierigkeitsstufe mit 20/35 gemeistert. Eins ist aber sicher: Wenn ich das Spiel erneut anfangen wÃ¼rde, hÃ¤tte ich wieder keine Ahnung was zu tun ist.

Zusammenfassung? Ein sehr gutes, aber verdammt schweres Spiel. Richtige Entscheidungen mÃ¼ssen auch nicht entscheidend sein, man braucht auch eine Handvoll GlÃ¼ck. Habt ihr nichts davon, habt ihr schon das zweite Trial verloren. Habt ihr beides? Tja, solange Chuck Norris nicht euer Vater ist, seht ihr kein Gold am Ende.

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198030862992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 610, 'last_played': 1496784290}
{'steamid': '76561198007240278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1485338857}
review:
It's a puzzle game. Two-ish hours to play through, tough enough that I failed the first time, interesting enough that I completed with a score of 11/35 on novice difficulty the second time, repetitive enough and cruel enough on any non-novice difficulty that I don't think I'm going to play through again - meeting even the first challenge at the lowest success level on "standard" difficulty seems to be entirely dependent on random events - but there's maybe $9 worth of interesting strategizing here, if you like the demo.

Two minor suggestions: the number of surprises in the game make it pretty hard to win on the first playthrough, even on the easiest difficulty; more foreshadowing or sense of pace would help. Also, Enter, space, or some other key as a shortcut for End Turn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005818530', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 331, 'last_played': 1520821315}
review: I've played the Pre-Civ series since the flash games. This game is still decently fun, but it strays a bit too much from the formula IMO, and ends up feeling like a normal boardgame too much. Because of how the tech tree is built, you actually can't stray from a breadth first approach very easily and end up doing a lot of the same build orders a lot unlike the previous games. Still a fun game but I'd recommend Marble Age over this if you had to choose.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985590072', 'num_games_owned': 1487, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1476754778}
review:
[h1]Notice: I had been provided a complimentary copy of Pre-Civilization Egypt by the developer, Clarus Victoria, for review purposes. These opinions are my own.[/h1]

Much like the prior Pre-Civilization games, this game is about doing "the right things, at the right times."  It's less of a game and more of a story that you must play over and over again, until you get it right.  Memorizing events and refining your play style until you do exactly what you need to do, in the correct order.

The game gives you very little breathing room; mistakes cost you the game, and a mistake can be as simple as choosing the wrong bonus.

A typical play through of a game is 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on how much you decide to read.  Your first play through, and likely several after, you will get crushed.  That's the point of these games - to get you to be as accurate as possible with your decisions and pass all the in-game trials.  It's a puzzle, afterall.

If I had any feedback: I'd love to see a Pre-Civilization game be much more forgiving.  All of the games in this series require you to be absolute in your decision making process.  Sometimes, I just want to have fun, rather than guess my way through a game a few times until I get it right.

Admittedly, I actually found Pre-Civilization Mable Age more fun than Egypt.  It felt longer and more forgiving; though the way in which Egypt is presented to you I like a heck of a lot more (It looks far less like a Flash or Mobile game, and more like an actual game).  The ending of Pre-Civilization Egypt will seriously sneak up on you during your first play through.  I was very taken back when the game was telling me I had only 17 turns left.  Felt short.

All in all, this is a game you'll play a few times and try to master, but unless you're extremely meticilious, you'll get frustrated and annoyed.  If you enjoyed any of the prior Pre-Civilization games, you'll enjoy Egypt: It's more of the same, presented better, yet shorter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986993215', 'num_games_owned': 293, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1476665026}
review:
Got through one play trhough yesterday. Already planning a second.

This is a game where you should absolutely not be afraid to fail. The entire game only takes a couple of hours, so it's not a huge loss to start over halfway through because you didn't balance something correctly or didn't know how a particilar mechanic should be used.

I really like the format of this game and I hope to see more like it. It has elements of a citybuilder and grand strategy, but is a bit more "linear" than your typical strategy game. This means that cities grow more organically and you get to focus on a scale of decisionmaking that makes sense for the scale of your empire. Early on, you are deciding which forest you want to forage in. End game, you are choosing what form of tribute you want from neighboring colonies so you can defeat your rival kingdom. This transition would be hard to pull off in a sandbox game.

I think this game is easily worth the full price. Hope to see some more games from this developer covering different eras of history (or fantasy/scifi)!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973064382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 102, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 102, 'last_played': 1476664789}
review: Inexpensive, fun game.  Especially if you enjoy history.  Seems a bit too linear but I'm enjoying it

author: {'steamid': '76561198030967964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1710, 'last_played': 1476936358}
review:
If you're at all interested in this game after looking at the screenshots, you should buy it.

It's not a graphical wonder.  It's a simple, well-paced game that thoughtfully walks you through the problems of an early agricultural society.  

The gameplay starts simple but really builds.  You'll likely only get one playthrough out of it.  Unless you're new to strategy games, you're unlikely to fail that playthrough, so choose some of the middle difficulty settings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008104899', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 713, 'last_played': 1477248952}
review:
If ever there was a game that you thought was at the least bit fun then this would not be the one.  You make little gif cards for your persons to do thing and they repeat the little animation ove and over with repative monotny.  There board is almost exactly the same every time you play it.  It is actually easier if you dont play beginner mode but that make very different in the effort.  The battles are decided by the computer is a completely uknown fashion and there is nothing you can do to make it come out differently.  

Really I thought this was a game up my alley but since you can never get through it with what appears to be any amount of success then it become tedious.  There must be a secret sequence like a puzzle to this game but what I wanted was a strategy game not a puzzle.
developer_response:
Hi! Thanks for your response â€“ we just released the version 1.0.1 which will help the player to feel himself as comfortable as possible, even implemented the training mode for the first-time players. Receiving the negative review are frustrating us, but also shows us the way to improve the game even more. It would be great if you will try the new version and tell us about the difference between the old game and the new one.

Regarding the â€œpuzzleâ€ as you called it. There are many kinds of strategy games â€“ tactical, economical, global, 4x, resource management etc. And even the most famous titles are â€œpuzzlesâ€ in your logic: X-Com â€“ linear story line with side missions, you free to choose only tactical decisions on pre-generated map; Tropico series â€“ complete the missions; Total war series â€“ buildings and cities. Each of this great titles has unique strategic features and fixed game elements. The same is with us â€“ our strategic feature is to choose different development tactics to successfully pass the trials and before the 1.0.1 update we were limited by the real Egyptian history and with the last update player can continue after the 220 turn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198286017559', 'num_games_owned': 2641, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 310, 'last_played': 1476666591}
review:
A strategy based on Ancient Egypt, it's a beautifully themed, and georgously looking little game for some hours of fun, it's the mini Ancient Egypt version of the Sid Meier's Civilization games. Though the replay value is not at all the same, I believe it's more of a one shot game that you will sure enjoy.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197996982051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1528, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1632136760}
review: on the easy mode it is almost imposable to win. you can not keep playing when the game is over. it idea of the game is great but it needs lots of tweking. i play civ 5 on close to the hardest mode and could not come close to wining one game
developer_response:
Hi Dave, thanks for the feedback even though it is negative. Such feedbacks are helping us to make the game better and better. Your review is no exception.

We just released the v.1.0.1 update, where we made the game for the beginner players as easier as possible. Now the players who just want to play like in open-world game can play in training mode and they are given the opportunity to continue playing after completion of the historical part of the campaign.

I hope that you will be able to evaluate it yourself and it will change your opinion about the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970967930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1477158212}
review:
Edit: After the developer replied and took the effort to talk to me about what their goal with the game was, I decided to let the fact that it's meant to be educational add in.

To that effect, it's a good effort to help bring out an insight into some actual Egyptian history and events. The part that actually made me turn the thumb up is that it offers enough to hold attention and appeal to curiosity without crushing peoples interest with text-blocks.

The gameplay itself is decent, nothing extraordinary but at least without any bugs that I've encountered to date which is an achivement in it's own right. 

I earlier said that the game was pricey for what it offered, but I am just a bitter git after all the indie-developers that has ripped people off and the many, many games that have just been disappointments.


Egypt Pre-Civilization makes no disillusions of what it is - A game to show you a window in time.
developer_response:
Greetings! Do you think the game deserves a negative review for 4 hours of gameplay (not including re-plays with different prologue options) and $8? If our game would only entertain the player, I would agree with you.

But playing our game you are getting the knowledge about history and culture of Pre-dynastic Egypt

 - The city that you build, is real one and now being excavated http://www.hierakonpolis-online.org .
- The building that you are constructing was reconstructed by the best archeologists and Egyptologists.
- Events in which you are participate, are bit by bit restored episodes of the history of the foundation of the Egyptian state.
- The discoveries that you making in the game is a real technological evolution of Egyptian civilization: many inventions were made on the banks of the Nile, about which we are telling in details in the descriptions and the game events.

Do you think that it's not worth movie ticket or burger+cola?

author: {'steamid': '76561198031404282', 'num_games_owned': 2376, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1476598691}
review:
TLDR: Only fun for the first hour or 2, then it's totally worthless

This game may feel like fun in the beginning, but then you realize that there is only one scenario to play and that's it..no modes, no campaign, no multiplayer..nothing

Also it's insanely difficult to win this one scenario even on the easiest settings..you will need to memorize what happens through out the game and pre-plan the next time based on stuff that hasn't happened yet, and in the end it will still be difficult!

Edit: So after the patch the game seems better, at least now one has the option to play an actual easy difficulty and finish the game without too much complex god-like strategy skills and memorization for what lies ahead. Normally I hate easy difficulties and like a good challenge, but in this case it felt way too hard on the easy difficulty and for the wrong reasons, and there isn't a clear way to know you'r not doiing well until the end of that game so it can be frustrating at that point.

Anyway, I realize I was a bit too harsh on tha game before, I probably expected too much of a 9$ game. And above all, the developers response have been awesome, and I value this almost as much as a good game. I wish them well, it's a good first try (if it is) and maybe we'll get better games from them in the future.

A note to the developer tho: yes I am from Egypt and I love storytelling in games, but it needs to be a bit less subtle to grab my attention, needs to play a bigger part somehow..it didn't really connect with me in the game.

I'm changing this to a positive review, for 9 bucks and a few hours, I did have some good fun even if it didn't last forever, but I guess that's fair :)
developer_response:
Hello and thanks for the review. The negative review is of course bad for us, but it helps to make the game better and better. We read your comments and just released the 1.0.1 update â€“ which we made as easy as possible for all novice players. They now can play in a training mode and after the historic campaign they can continue to play.

About mods â€“ we're working on Steam Workshop now and when it will be ready, we give the players all the game scripts so they can create their own mods.

Recommended game time is 3-4 hours, during this period, the game will tell you about the ancient history of your country (You're from Cairo, right?), what technologies were discovered by the Egyptians thousands of years ago and will shows you where people lived and what difficulties they have met.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007360038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 3004, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2898, 'last_played': 1477410624}
review:
Pre-Civilization Egypt is part simulation, part history lesson. It's highly atmospheric, and very addictive in that 'just one more turn' sort of way. Multiple levels of difficulty make for high replayability, too. Be warned: the game comes to a very abrupt end -- by design -- in about 3000 BC (something that I find quite refreshing -- some games these days can drag on far too long!).

I've played it through twice now, and lost both times (the second time by just one turn, curse it!). Each playthrough took me about ten hours, and as I'm sure I'll try it again, I consider this game excellent value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040510830', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1476572577}
review:
Acabada mi primera partida tras casi 4 horas de juego, aquÃ­ va mi pequeÃ±o granito de arena para recomendar este juego a los usuarios de habla hispana de STEAM. Pre-Civilization Egypt es uno de esos tÃ­tulos que no pueden faltar en la estanterÃ­a digital de cualquier amante de la estrategia, y sobre todo de un amante de la historia, y del antiguo Egipto en particular, pues es en este aspecto donde el tÃ­tulo estÃ¡ cuidado al detalle. 

El trasfondo del juego gira en torno a los esfuerzos que tendrÃ¡s que realizar para conseguir que una tribu nÃ³mada instalada en la ribera del rÃ­o Nilo termine convirtiÃ©ndose en uno de los principales proto-estados del perÃ­odo pre-dinÃ¡stico desde donde parta el esfuerzo unificador del Alto y Bajo Egipto que iniciÃ³ el perÃ­odo de los faraones. No estamos hablando, por tanto, de un juego que se desarrolla en el Egipto que la mayorÃ­a de gente conoce, el de su plenitud como civilizaciÃ³n, sino  que se centra en los orÃ­genes del mismo. Este trasfondo, en mi opiniÃ³n, le otorga al tÃ­tulo de un mayor interÃ©s.

La mecÃ¡nica del juego es simple, pero a la vez guarda una complejidad interesante. Su simplicidad nace de su modo de juego, tipo tablero y basado en turnos (TBS), donde tendremos que gestionar los recursos disponibles en las distintas casillas del tablero mediante mano de obra. Ahora bien, la complejidad antes mencionada nace en el desarrollo de la partida, cuando nos damos cuenta que, poco a poco, las decisiones que tomamos tienen que estar enfocadas a intentar conseguir los â€œresultados histÃ³ricosâ€ que la partida nos va presentando. AsÃ­, te das cuenta que para ganar la partida tendrÃ¡s que utilizar todas las opciones que tengas disponibles, sin maximificar unas en detenimiento de otras. De nada te servirÃ¡, por ejemplo, centrar tus esfuerzos en un campo concreto descuidando los otros, porque en unos turnos posteriores verÃ¡s cÃ³mo la decisiÃ³n que tomaste de centrar tus esfuerzos en conseguir x recurso te han debilitado en otro aspecto, lo que te lleva a no conseguir los objetivos con los que el juego te reta.

Este planteamiento, tiene sus pros y sus contras. Por un lado, hace difÃ­cil conseguir una victoria total centrÃ¡ndote en un tipo de estrategia (por ejemplo, usando un enfoque militarista expansionista clÃ¡sico, basado en atacar a todo bicho viviente del mapa de campaÃ±a), lo que mÃ¡s dinamismo en el planteamiento de estrategias. Ahora bien, al existir la cuestiÃ³n de los â€œresultados histÃ³ricosâ€ hace que la aproximaciÃ³n a cualquier partida acabe desarrollÃ¡ndose de forma lineal, pues la gran mayorÃ­a de eventos importantes o evoluciÃ³n de la tribu se desarrolla siempre de la misma forma, y no hay posibilidad de cambiarlo. Vamos, tienes que ir de A hacia D, y sabes que entre una letra y otra hay inequÃ­vocamente B y C. La gracia, sin embargo, se encuentra en saber conseguir la forma mÃ¡s eficiente de llegar al final de un camino ya marcado, de ahÃ­ que los desarrolladores hayan marcado un sistema de puntuaciÃ³n de 0 a 35 puntos que se otorgan al final de la partida segÃºn los objetivos cumplidos y la forma de conseguirlos (en mi caso, en mi primera partida he conseguido la friolera de 3/35 puntos). Intentar mejorar el enfoque de nuestras partidas para asÃ­ conseguir mÃ¡s puntuaciÃ³n al final, es el caramelo que los desarrolladores han dejado para intentar garantizar una cierta rejugabilidad.

Entiendo, sin embargo, que este modo de juego tenga sus defensores y sus detractores. En mi caso, no me parece mal la mecÃ¡nica, aunque sÃ­ que es cierto que esta â€œfalta de libertadâ€ pueda resultar frustrante en segÃºn quÃ© compases del juego.

Saliendo de este tema, y centrÃ¡ndonos en aspectos tÃ©cnicos y contextuales, el juego es una delicia. Visualmente es precioso, y se aprecia en los detalles de ilustraciones dibujadas a mano, o en las fichas de trabajadores que simulan, por asÃ­ decirlo, representaciones pictÃ³ricas de arte del antiguo egipcio. La mÃºsica y efectos de sonido son magnÃ­ficos, y consiguen el efecto de introducirte en el juego aunque tenga grÃ¡ficos â€œsimplesâ€. En resumen: entra como un guante por los ojos y los oÃ­dos a aquellas personas que buscan una experiencia de juego tranquila y relajada.
QuizÃ¡s, sin embargo, es en el aspecto histÃ³rico donde el juego destaca como en ningÃºn otro. La profusiÃ³n de detalles histÃ³ricos â€œrealesâ€(que aparecen en la historiografÃ­a, vamos) con los eventos fijos que te guÃ­an en la partida, asÃ­ como los aleatorios, y los pequeÃ±os detalles que surgen de vez en cuando (nombres, ciudades, evoluciÃ³n de la religiosidad y los cultosâ€¦), hacen que el tÃ­tulo sea un verdadero documental sobre el perÃ­odo en el que se centra. Cuando uno termina una partida, creo que se puede hacer una idea mÃ¡s o menos general, de cÃ³mo consiguiÃ³ desarrollarse en aquella regiÃ³n una cultura tan interesante y peculiar como fue la del antiguo Egipto.

Por tanto, y en resumen, el juego vale bien sus 8 â‚¬ que cuesta. No pretende ser un gran tÃ­tulo de estrategia que te robe eones de tu tiempo libre, sino un juego que pretende mostrarte, mediante una mecÃ¡nica entretenida, un perÃ­odo histÃ³rico fascinante. Posiblemente muchos lo guarden en su estanterÃ­a digital una vez completada su primera partida. Otros le darÃ¡n otra oportunidad para probar distintos enfoques. En todo caso, estÃ¡ claro que la mayorÃ­a pasarÃ©is un buen rato con Ã©l, que bien puede valer el precio invertido.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998391818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 6042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4130, 'last_played': 1623642391}
review:
A relaxing turn-by-turn strategy/puzzle game about resource management. Each play-through runs into the same major events, but there are minor events that mix it up a bit. Knowing the major events coming up is part of the gameplay, so it doesn't really feel unreplayable.

For some reason it reminds me about the 12 Tasks of Hercules series, though it plays nothing like those games. Probably because, at it's core, it is about resource management.

It's got an original slant, it's atmospheric, and I'd love to see more of these.

UPDATE: And now that I'm a bit further along in played hours, I find it kind've relaxing. A bit like playing solitaire: you know what the tasks are, but how you get there is the trick, and no one game is going to knock your socks off.

author: {'steamid': '76561198220646841', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1476641113}
review:
The game mechanincs is very similar to Sid Meier's Civilization, and is focused on the historical events that lead to the rise of the Egyptian unified empire. I recommend this game because I had fun playing it, and also because of it's historical accuracy. After playing Egypt Pre-civilization, the player will have an understanding of the events and factors responsible for the development of the ancient Egyptian civilization that would be otherwise difficult or boring to many people to obtain by just reading books and academic papers. I think Egypt Pre-civilization is an example of how video games are an excelent tool to teach knowledge of the real world.

This game is for you if:

* You like Sid Meier's Civilization
* You are interested in ancient Egypt or ancient history

This game is not for you if:

* You are looking for a game as good or better than Sid Meier's Civilization
* You're not interested in Egyptian history at all

Other factors that can drive away people from this game is that is very linear, following the sequence of events that lead to the unification of the Egyptian empire, and that it may be very difficult to win. But again, these drawbacks are otherwise contributing to achieve perhaps the main goal of the game: teach ancient Egyptian history. On the other hand, I really liked the art design, it's beautiful and captures very well the character of Egyptian art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049391306', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 1217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1528222772}
review:
This game offers a very rich historical gaming experience and oh boy does it deliver!


It's an educational linear turn-based historical simulation strategy that will lead you through the history of Ancient Egypt. Starting from 5000 B.C. you will guide the nomadic and humble Egyptian tribe through all the hardships to prosperity and power culminating in the Unification of Lower and Upper Egypt. Get ready to witness evolutionary breakthroughs that enabled early Egyptians to march into faraway lands, fight catastrophes, hardships and ultimately establish first Egyptian state. Will you be able to re-enact the events that unfolded historically or will you doom your fledgling chiefdom into forgotten annals of history? Get an intimate knowledge about events that took place before the Classic Egypt eras through this unique game.


This game really made me understand the evolution of the Egyptian civilization. It all makes so much sense now! It really made me understand the whole history of the area much more. This is such an interesting chapter of the human history and developers have done an amazing job at portraying first steps of the human civilizational evolution in Egypt! 

I really like the ambient of the game, background music, voices, the way upgrades are applied on the map, the way your tribe evolves from meager beginnings to a powerful state, the paintings that are shown when a major event happens, etc. There is a lot of replayability in it too because there's always a new strategy you would like to try out to better the results and maybe delve into higher difficulties and see how your strategic wisdom (or it's lack) will bode for the people you guide.   

The game is not too simple and not too hard, it does stuff very nicely. It is rather unique in what it does. At the release the game did end rather abruptly and the unification warning did not trigger soon enough to warn the player. Wasn't able to complete it because the game didn't provide me with enough information. This has been resolved in the patch now.  

My expectations for this game were fulfilled, love playing it. I usually wait for the game to get discounted but after I tried the demo I couldn't wait and immediately bought it.  

I did more re-runs on higher difficulties. When modding tools get introduced for it more gaming will be squeezed out of it.  


I would recommend the game especially now that it got patched.  

I rate the game on 5-point scale:

Music and sounds 5
Gameplay 4
Graphics 5
Historical accuracy 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198157772708', 'num_games_owned': 424, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1527194030}
review: I've played the game since they gave me a demo in a greenlight phase.Even then I knew that game had great potencial.If you like history of Egypt and history itself you will like this game.When you start It is it looks like it is a easy going casual game(so I tought in the beggining).But after playing a while your decisions on the start can cost in middle and in my case in the last two turns.So started again I thought it would be easier the second time with a different approachand found out the game concept is much deeper that I thought.The concept of the game is to make wise decisions for your,where you have to balance food and production in the beggining and later on warfare and trade are added.Great game in general looking at the given price and content ratio.Try it and enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993272164', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 353, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 353, 'last_played': 1476478823}
review:
First of, this isn't a typical civ-game. It's more like a "find-the-right-path-or-die" rogue-like adventure game with resource allocation mixed in.

It is pretty, sets a good mood and is quick enough to play a few times during an evening.

First round I played I got my ass handed to me in the end as I did not complete many of the required events.
Maybe I was foolhardy to go with "medium" difficulty too...

Second game I actually managed to win on "easy", mostly because I knew which events where gonna happen.

My game score was just 9 though. I thought I did great and completed the first four events on Gold but I guess some of the later ones are worth more...and that you can infact lose points by wiping out one of the tribes too fast, as I did.

Worth the money I guess, if you are not frustrated by low to no replayability once you finished it.
